Physically Defensive (Grass).description: Mega Venusaur excels as a wall on Grass teams, effectively tanking Fire- and Ice-type hits with its Thick Fat ability. It relies on Sludge Bomb as its main attack, dealing with Grass- and Fairy-types—such as Rillaboom and Iron Valiant—while also poisoning walls like Mega Sableye, Iron Hands, and Porygon2. Synthesis provides reliable healing, which, combined with Leech Seed and Sludge Bomb's poison, allows Mega Venusaur to wear down foes such as Garchomp. Hidden Power Fire handles Steel-types like Mega Scizor, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo, although Earth Power can also be used to answer Steel-, Poison- and Fire-types such as Heatran and Iron Moth. The Speed EVs allow Mega Venusaur to outpace Adamant Azumarill. Mega Venusaur's teammates greatly appreciate its ability to handle threats like Mega Diancie and Mega Scizor and clear Toxic Spikes. Ferrothorn and Cradily form a solid defensive core, absorbing hits from Flying- and Psychic-types such as Galarian Moltres and Tapu Lele, while Mega Venusaur tanks Fire-, Ice-, and Fighting-type attacks. Whimsicott and Tapu Bulu help with the Dragon matchup, and Celebi handles the problematic Poison-types like Toxapex and Nidoking. Rillaboom and Breloom provide strong priority, allowing them to threaten faster threats such as Nihilego. Rillaboom also sets up Grassy Terrain to supply additional passive recovery along with Mega Venusaur's Leech Seed, boosting longevity. Meowscarada and Zarude serve as speedy wallbreakers that are capable of breaking through walls such as Clodsire and Skeledirge. Both also benefit from pivoting into Mega Venusaur to tank attacks from the aforementioned Fighting-, Fire-, and Ice-types.

Physically Defensive (Poison).description: Mega Venusaur finds a solid position on Poison teams thanks to its secondary Grass typing, good natural bulk, and helpful set of tools. Giga Drain threatens Water- and Ground-types like Barraskewda, Swampert, and Great Tusk. Hidden Power Fire is used to deal with Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. Leech Seed provides recovery and forces out bulky targets such as Blissey. Earth Power threatens Fire- and Poison-type targets like non-Air Balloon Heatran and Toxapex. Sludge Bomb handles Fairy- and Grass-types like Mega Altaria, Tapu Koko, and Ogerpon-W along with being able to spread poison, thus chipping foes down. The given EV spread is used to maximize Mega Venusaur's bulk while still allowing it to outspeed Adamant Azumarill. Alolan Muk serves as a solid partner for Mega Venusaur, being a specially defensive wall capable of threatening Psychic- and Ghost-types like Tapu Lele, Galarian Slowking, Blacephalon, and Gholdengo. Galarian Slowking can handle threats such as Volcarona, Zapdos, and Kyurem, which easily blast through Mega Venusaur. Crobat provides Defog support, granting Mega Venusaur safe entry, and it can also deal with threats such as Mega Gallade with Brave Bird and Substitute Hydreigon with Infiltrator Toxic. Toxapex complements Mega Venusaur as a physically defensive wall, capable of taking on foes like Mega Scizor, Galarian Zapdos, and Weavile along with providing Z-Haze for boosted threats like Kommo-o. Offensive threats like Sneasler, Nidoking, and Nihilego appreciate Mega Venusaur being able to take hits from bulky Ground-types like Clodsire and Hippowdon. In response, Sneasler can remove specially defensive threats like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey thanks to its powerful Close Combat, Nidoking can remove threats like Corviknight, Gliscor, and Gholdengo thanks to its diverse and offensive movepool, and Nihilego can handle Fire- and Flying-type threats like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Tornadus-T.

Dragon Dance (Fire).description: Mega Charizard X is a ferocious wallbreaker and setup sweeper, aiding Fire teams in matchups like Dragon, Fire, and Electric. Tough Claws-boosted Flare Blitz fires off nuclear-powered attacks, heavily denting walls such as Mandibuzz, Gliscor, and Mega Sableye. Dragon Claw, also powered up by Tough Claws, threatens Garchomp, Rotom-W, and Kommo-o. Earthquake threatens switch-ins like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Heatran, while Roost increases Mega Charizard X's longevity and mitigate recoil damage from Flare Blitz. Alternatively, Thunder Punch may be used to deal more damage to Slowbro, Pelipper, and Tapu Fini while still retaining super effective coverage against Toxapex. Volcarona is an exceptional teammate, as it threatens physical walls such as Slowbro, Toxapex, and Hippowdon after a Quiver Dance. Torkoal supports Mega Charizard X with sun to boost Flare Blitz's power and remove rain, Stealth Rock to wear down switch-ins, and Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards. Rotom-H sets up Reflect and Light Screen to ease Mega Charizard X's setup process and offers pivoting with Volt Switch. Choice Scarf Blacephalon is a great late-game cleaner and is appreciated to wear down troublesome walls like Skeledirge and Slowbro as well as cripple Toxapex and Porygon2 with Trick. Heatran traps and withers down Toxapex with Magma Storm and prevents Stealth Rock from being set up using Taunt. Cinderace provides entry hazard control with Court Change and brings Mega Charizard X in using U-turn.

Sun Wallbreaker (Flying).description: Mega Charizard Y makes for a great wallbreaker on Flying teams. Fire Blast, although it has lower accuracy, can be used over Flamethrower, notably 2HKOing Alolan Muk and Clodsire under sun. Solar Beam covers Water-types that resist Flamethrower like Swampert and Rotom-W, and thanks to sun, it does not need to charge. Focus Blast targets Dark- and Steel-types such as Hydreigon and Heatran. Alternatively, Scorching Sands can be used to target Heatran more reliably, as well as providing coverage against Toxapex and Iron Hands, the latter of which can be greatly hindered thanks to the burn chance. Hidden Power Electric can be run over Roost to greatly threaten Water teams in tandem with Solar Beam, threatening the likes of Pelipper, Mantine, and Gyarados. Dragonite and Mega Charizard Y form a great offensive pairing, with Mega Charizard Y threatening physically bulky threats like Mega Scizor and Corviknight for Dragonite, while Dragonite acts as a late-game sweeper and deals with Alolan Muk and Nihilego for Mega Charizard Y. Corviknight and Mantine are essential teammates, as they remove Stealth Rock with Defog, which would otherwise effectively leave Mega Charizard Y out of the match. Corviknight also brings Mega Charizard Y in with U-turn, while Mantine helps against rain teams, taking hits from Barraskewda and Mega Swampert. In turn, Mega Charizard Y takes out threats to them both like Rotom-W and Magnezone. It also appreciates entry hazard support from Landorus and Gliscor wearing down foes to help it wallbreak more easily, while both setters also provide an Electric immunity. In return, Mega Charizard Y handles Ice-types like Articuno and Mamoswine. Enamorus makes for a great partner because it handles Dark-types like Weavile and Greninja and provides Healing Wish support; it appreciates the removal of bulky Steel-types in return.

Bird Jesus (Normal).description: Mega Pidgeot is one of the premier special attackers Normal teams have access to because of its good Speed tier and a powerful, coveted STAB move in Hurricane that beats nuisances to Normal teams like Kommo-o and Ogerpon-W while never missing. Heat Wave complements Hurricane well by heavily damaging Steel-types like Jirachi, Ferrothorn, and Mega Scizor, which makes Mega Pidgeot very effective against Psychic, Grass, and Bug teams. Roost heightens Mega Pidgeot's longevity by taking advantage of defensive Pokemon that can't hit it very hard, such as Mega Sableye and Slowbro. In the last slot, Toxic's ability to cripple switch-ins like Iron Hands, Rotom-W, and Mantine is preferred, but U-turn is valuable to keep momentum and flee from checks such as Heatran and Alolan Muk. Ursaluna forms an incredible wallbreaking core with Mega Pidgeot; it is able to demolish special walls like Clodsire and Hisuian Goodra and can switch into Electric-type moves that target the bird. In return, Mega Pidgeot helps Ursaluna beat physical walls like Mega Venusaur and Skarmory, revenge kills Grass- and Fighting-types such as Ogerpon-W and Keldeo that threaten the bear, and is able to U-turn into Ursaluna so it activates its Flame Orb safely. Staraptor is a great defensive pivot that removes entry hazards for Mega Pidgeot and brings it into the field unscathed with U-turn. Similarly, Chansey, Blissey, and Porygon2 are very bulky partners that can switch into most attacks aimed at Mega Pidgeot and pivot into it via Teleport. Chansey and Blissey also lay down Stealth Rock to help Mega Pidgeot net more KOs, notably letting it OHKO Mega Venusaur and 2HKO Toxapex with Hurricane.

Surge Surfer (Electric).description: Alolan Raichu surfs on Electric Terrain, blitzing past even the fastest Choice Scarf users in Greninja and Meowscarada and Swift Swim and Sand Rush users in Mega Swampert and Excadrill, which threaten to overwhelm Electric teams. Nasty Plot provides Alolan Raichu with the much-needed boost to OHKO Gliscor, Sinistcha, and Iron Hands with Shattered Psyche. Psyshock is preferred when using Life Orb, as it dispatches special walls like Clodsire and Galarian Slowking after minimal chip damage. Life Orb also lets Alolan Raichu OHKO Alolan Muk and Rotom-W with Rising Voltage at +2. Grass Knot and Focus Blast heavily damage Pokemon that scoff at its Electric- and Psychic-type moves like Mega Swampert, Iron Treads, and Hydreigon. However, it is to be noted that Alolan Raichu requires a Life Orb to have a shot at OHKOing Hydreigon. Normaum Z with Hyper Beam may be considered, as it pummels through targets Grass Knot covers on top of heavily damaging Mega Latias, which typically overwhelms Electric teams. Tapu Koko is a mandatory teammate for Alolan Raichu, as it sets Electric Terrain, deals with Dragon-types like Mega Altaria and Roaring Moon, and pressures Flying and Water teams extremely well due to its wide coverage. Physical attackers like Zeraora and Iron Hands help against special walls like Ting-Lu, Blissey, and Hisuian Goodra that Alolan Raichu struggles against. Ground-immune teammates like Zapdos and Rotom-W are appreciated, as they not only switch in against speedy threats like Sand Rush Excadrill and Choice Scarf Iron Treads when Electric Terrain ends but also deal with Grass- and Ground-types like Celebi and Great Tusk.

Wallbreaker (Poison).description: Nidoking finds a solid place on Poison teams as the premier special attacker thanks to Sheer Force and its solid movepool giving it a unique role of helping with the Steel matchup. Earth Power demolishes the Steel- and Poison-types that can easily come in on its teammates such as Heatran, Gholdengo, and Toxapex. Flamethrower deals with Steel-types not threatened by Earth Power such as Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Scizor. Ice Beam removes problematic Ground- and Flying-types like Hippowdon, Gliscor, and Zapdos. Stealth Rock can help chip foes that can swap into Earth Power like Mega Charizard Y. Alternatively, Thunderbolt can be run to complete the BoltBeam coverage and hit Water-types like Pelipper, Dondozo, and Mantine, which otherwise wall Nidoking. Choice Scarf Sneasler forms a solid offensive core with Nidoking. Sneasler not only removes specially defensive targets like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey, but also removes faster targets like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona if running Rock Slide, while Nidoking deals with threats that would stop Sneasler like Gholdengo and Toxapex. Mega Venusaur handles the Water- and Ground-type foes that would overwhelm Nidoking such as Barraskewda, Mega Gyarados, Swampert, and Mamoswine. Alolan Muk deals with Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Hisuian Zoroark, Alolan Raichu, and Tapu Lele, which pose a significant issue for Nidoking. Galarian Slowking can take on threats such as Choice Specs Latios and Tornadus-T and use Future Sight to help overwhelm special walls like Swampert. Crobat is immune to Ground-type moves from Pokemon like Great Tusk, can use Defog to remove entry hazards to provide safe entry for Nidoking, and can deal with threats like Mega Gallade

Calm Mind.description:
60 Spe EVs lets Clefable outspeed Corviknight.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Aurora Veil (Ice).description: With access to Snow Warning and Aurora Veil, a great typing, and a key Speed tier that lets it deal with the likes of Keldeo and Urshifu-R, Alolan Ninetales proves to be extremely useful for Ice teams. Freeze-Dry makes it a menace in the Water matchup, dealing heavy damage to Swampert, Gastrodon, and Pelipper. Encore enables Alolan Ninetales to disrupt walls and slower setup sweepers like Ting-Lu and Tapu Fini. Alolan Ninetales's teammates appreciate its supportive capabilities; setup sweepers like Swords Dance Weavile and Dragon Dance Baxcalibur have a lot more setup opportunities, and offensive Pokemon like Galarian Darmanitan have an easier time switching in. Cloyster is a stellar partner; its defensive set removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin and sets Spikes to wear down Keldeo and Toxapex for Alolan Ninetales, while Shell Smash variants can more easily set up with its assistance. SubRoost Kyurem helps Alolan Ninetales pressure Water teams with its own Freeze-Dry and checks Fighting-types like Galarian Zapdos with a Chople Berry. Piloswine lays down Stealth Rock and switches into and checks a variety of Fire-types that Alolan Ninetales hates, such as Volcarona and Iron Moth.

Assault Vest (Poison).description: Assault Vest Alolan Muk finds a pivotal role on Poison teams, with its high special bulk and secondary Dark typing providing a much-needed immunity to Psychic-type attacks. Knock Off provides a strong STAB option with immense utility by removing held items. Poison Jab is Alolan Muk's most consistent STAB move, being able to reliably spread poison and make progress thanks to Poison Touch. Pursuit is used to trap Choice-locked threats like Hisuian Zoroark, Greninja, and Tapu Lele for solid damage. For Alolan Muk's final moveslot, Drain Punch provides some much-needed recovery and hits Steel- and Dark-type threats like Heatran and Hydreigon for solid damage. Alternatively, Shadow Sneak can allow Alolan Muk to pick off weakened threats, while Rock Slide checks Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. The EV spread maximizes Alolan Muk's special bulk, with the 12 Defense EVs allowing it to survive an unboosted Victini's V-create after Stealth Rock. Crobat complements Alolan Muk thanks to its secondary Flying typing, which can support Alolan Muk against threats like Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Mega Gallade. Mega Venusuar helps Alolan Muk by dealing with Water- and Ground-type threats including Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Mamoswine. Galarian Slowking pairs with Alolan Muk to create a specially defensive core by handling threats such Choice Specs Latios, Tornadus-T, and Kyurem. Toxapex handles powerful physical threats like Kleavor, Mega Lopunny, and Weavile and has Z-Haze for special attackers that can overwhelm Alolan Muk like Kommo-o. Choice Scarf Sneasler can remove threats to Alolan Muk such as Excadrill, Hisuian Arcanine, and non-Choice Scarf Iron Boulder with its powerful Close Combat. Nidoking can remove walls that can sit on Alolan Muk, including Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight, thanks to its strong coverage moves.

Specially Defensive (Dark).description: Alolan Muk is an amazing defensive part of any Dark team, with its Poison typing and an amazing Special Defense stat providing Dark a comfortable switch-in to the likes of special Iron Valiant, Enamorus, Volcarona, and Tapu Lele. Poison Touch gives Alolan Muk the ability to poison common switch-ins such as Great Tusk, Rotom-W, and Zapdos. Poison Jab provides an accurate and solid way to deal damage to Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Tapu Koko. Knock Off makes progress against item-reliant Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Celesteela. Pursuit grants Alolan Muk the ability to trap Pokemon like Alolan Raichu, Gholdengo, and Galarian Slowking that attempt to switch out against it. Alternatively, Drain Punch gives Alolan Muk both another form of recovery and a tool to deal with Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Heatran, and Hydreigon. Finally, Protect can allow Alolan Muk to scout Choice-locked threats such as Meowscarada and Enamorus and take advantage of Black Sludge recovery. Investing 20 EVs in Attack helps Alolan Muk always break Kyurem's Substitute with Poison Jab. Mandibuzz is a great partner to complement Alolan Muk, as its immunity to Ground makes it easier to switch into threats such as Excadrill, Garchomp, and Great Tusk. and it has access to Defog to remove entry hazards that would whittle down Alolan Muk, allowing it to make the most out of Black Sludge. Furthermore, Mandibuzz checks physical setup sweepers like Scizor and Mega Gallade by using Foul Play. With its Ghost typing and Will-O-Wisp, Mega Sableye can handle threatening Fighting-types such as Sneasler, Iron Hands, and Mega Gallade. Mega Sableye is also excellent to pair with Alolan Muk, as it grants Dark a bulky Magic Bounce user. Meowscarada helps threaten out several Water- and Ground-type threats that threaten Alolan Muk like Choice Band Urshifu-R, Mega Swampert, and Great Tusk with its powerful Flower Trick. Both Hydreigon and Weavile appreciate having Alolan Muk on the team. as it can effectively Pursuit trap Tapu Lele. Alolan Muk complements Ting-Lu's hazard-stacking capabilities by spreading poison to wear down foes or removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Hydreigon is a wallbreaker that checks defensive Pokemon that Alolan Muk struggles to break like Hippowdon, opposing Alolan Muk, and Toxapex. Weavile checks Ground-, Dragon-, and Flying-types such as Garchomp, Mega Altaria, and Landorus.

Swords Dance (Bug).description: Mega Pinsir is a great late-game sweeper and one of Bug's best answers to Fighting-types thanks to its typing and Aerilate ability. Swords Dance boosts its power even further, overpowering foes such as Toxapex and Celesteela. Return is its main Flying-type STAB move, hitting Grass-, Bug-, and Fighting-types such as Mega Venusaur, Volcarona, and Kommo-o,. Using Frustration with 0 happiness is also an option, as it prevents Ditto from doing too much damage after copying Mega Pinsir. Quick Attack allows Mega Pinsir to revenge kill fast threats such as Iron Valiant, Ogerpon-H, and +1 Kommo-o. Close Combat nails Steel- and Rock-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Tyranitar, but Earthquake is also viable to hit Gholdengo and Aegislash, as well as Fire-types such as Torkoal and Volcanion. Mega Pinsir's secondary Flying typing makes it 4x weak to Stealth Rock, so it appreciates entry hazard removal from Rapid Spin users such as Forretress and Armaldo. Forretress also provides great defensive utility, taking physical Flying- and Rock-type moves with ease while having Volt Switch to pivot Mega Pinsir onto the field safely. Mega Pinsir appreciates entry hazards on the opposing side as well, such as Stealth Rock from Kleavor, Spikes and Toxic Spikes from Forretress, and Sticky Web from Araquanid and Galvantula. Furthermore, Kleavor can deal with Flying- and Fire-types such as Zapdos and Moltres, and Araquanid can deal with Fire-types as well as take on strong special attacks from the likes of Tapu Lele and Gholdengo, dealing damage back with Mirror Coat. Araquanid's access to Magic Coat allows it to deflect status and hazards as well. Scizor can check Ice- and Rock-types such as Baxcalibur and Ogerpon-C with its STAB Bullet Punch, as well as pivot with U-turn and remove Stealth Rock with Defog. Choice Scarf Buzzwole is a great partner and revenge killer, being able to wipe out the remaining foes if Mega Pinsir is knocked out. Volcarona appreciates Mega Pinsir's ability to deal with Kommo-o and Mega Venusaur, and in return, it acts as a special sweeper that can deal with physical walls such as Skarmory. Lokix is a great revenge killer thanks to its strong First Impression putting foes into range of Mega Pinsir's Quick Attack. Its access to Throat Chop and Knock Off also deals with Ghost-types, and the former prevents Skeledirge from using Torch Song, which would otherwise be a pain to deal with, while the latter removes items. Equipping Lokix with a Z-Crystal, such as Buginium Z or Darkinium Z, can deal massive damage to foes that would otherwise be difficult to break through.

Scarf Imposter.description: Ditto solidifies itself to once again be the goo that holds balanced and offensive Normal teams together thanks to its incredibly strong ability in Imposter. Reversing the momentum of fast offensive threats such as Iron Valiant, Mega Charizard X, and Excadrill allows Ditto to force counterplay against offensive teams. Ditto can also take advantage of entry hazard setters and removers, such as Ferrothorn, Kleavor, and Zapdos, using their own longevity or utility against them. In order to take advantage of Pokémon that use either Return or Frustration, such as Mega Altaria or Mega Pinsir, Ditto likes to run 128 Happiness instead of 255 or 0. Walls like Blissey and Porygon2 appreciate Ditto being able to prevent threats such as Baxcalibur and Spectrier from using them as setup fodder, while Ditto appreciates both defensive switch-ins and slow pivots via their use of Teleport. Mega Lopunny is a staple on Normal teams that accents Ditto's role expertly; many of the offensive threats and setup sweepers that revenge kill Mega Lopunny, such as Mega Charizard X, Kommo-o, and Galarian Moltres, are usually very weak to their own sets or coverage. Mega Lopunny can lure a threat in and pivot with U-turn, allowing Ditto to come in safely and transform. Ditto appreciates Mega Lopunny's Speed tier and fast pivot with U-turn, as well as potentially setting up Ditto with Encore Sets to stop foes from using Substitute or setting up completely. Hisuian Zoroark makes for another stellar teammate for Ditto, as Hisuian Zoroark disguised as a passive Pokemon, such as Blissey, or another offensive threat, such as Diggersby or Mega Lopunny, can lead to Hisuian Zoroark wallbreaking and netting KOs on vital foes, making it easier for Ditto to sweep once it has transformed. While Ditto is immune to Sticky Web, it is susceptible to other hazards such as Stealth Rock and Toxic Spikes, so forms of hazard control such as Staraptor or Cyclizar are appreciated. Staraptor is another defensive option, while Cyclizar can enable Ditto to utilize Transform with a Substitute from Shed Tail. Smeargle on more offense-oriented teams' pairs well with Ditto, as Smeargle can set hazards with Stone Axe or Ceaseless Edge and spread status with Nuzzle, Mortal Spin, or Spore, allowing Ditto to exploit the opposing team easier. Smeargle will usually give up Sticky Web when paired with Ditto so as to not hinder Ditto's revenge killing prowess.

Offensive Utility (Flying).description: By virtue of its great coverage as well as its sky-high Attack and Speed, Mega Aerodactyl finds a great spot on Flying teams as a late-game cleaner. Earthquake pairs well with Stone Edge, threatening the likes of Heatran and Hisuian Goodra and OHKOing Tapu Koko after Stealth Rock damage. Ice Fang is a great coverage option against Ground- and Dragon-types such as Landorus and Garchomp. Dual Wingbeat breaks through Fighting- and Grass-types such as Kommo-o, Mega Gallade, and Ogerpon-W. Pursuit allows Mega Aerodactyl to take advantage of foes like Victini and Latias that are forced out due to being Choice-locked into an undesirable move, and it punishes Gholdengo if it switches out expecting Earthquake. Stealth Rock aids both Mega Aerodactyl and its teammates in their wallbreaking or sweeping, while Taunt shuts down passive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Mantine and Corviknight are essential teammates, as they remove Stealth Rock with Defog so that Mega Aerodactyl finds more opportunities to switch in; they also provide a defensive backbone to shield Mega Aerodactyl from Water- and Ice-types like Mega Swampert and Choice Scarf Weavile. In return, Mega Aerodactyl deals with Fire- and Electric-types that the two of them hate like Volcarona, Zapdos, and Zeraora. Moltres is helpful in dealing with Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn. Landorus and Gliscor both set up entry hazards to aid Mega Aerodactyl in its cleaning when it's not running Stealth Rock; the two of them also act as stallbreakers, provide an Electric immunity, and bust through Toxapex. Despite its great Speed tier, Mega Aerodactyl is outsped by Kommo-o and Hisuian Lilligant at +1 and by Choice Scarf users such as Nihilego, making Choice Scarf Enamorus a great teammate that is able to revenge kill these threats. Special wallbreakers like Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Thundurus-T deal with physically defensive walls like Celesteela, Slowbro, and Ferrothorn, which would otherwise wall Mega Aerodactyl; they can also pivot Mega Aerodactyl in against specially defensive walls like Galarian Slowking and Hisuian Goodra.

Choice Specs (Electric).description: With Choice Specs equipped, Zapdos's already amazing Special Attack is boosted to even greater heights, turning it into an incredible wallbreaker. Its Flying typing also grants an invaluable Ground immunity for Electric teams. Hurricane is Zapdos's most powerful move, threatening a variety of Pokemon that resist or are immune to Electric such as Mega Venusaur and Gastrodon. Heat Wave beats Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Iron Treads, and Ferrothorn, thus making it an incredible asset in the Steel and Grass matchups. Hidden Power Ice cleanly OHKOes Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp; alternatively, Hidden Power Grass can be used if reliably eliminating Gastrodon and Swampert is more important. Volt Switch lets Zapdos switch out of its checks like Tyranitar and Blissey, keeping momentum in favor of Zapdos's team. As dangerous as Zapdos is, it is highly susceptible to Stealth Rock; hence, Rotom-W is a great partner that can use Defog while also helping Zapdos beat Ground-types thanks to Hydro Pump. Iron Hands and Zeraora help Zapdos wallbreak by wearing down special walls like Heatran, Blissey, and Clodsire. Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can take advantage of Zapdos weakening teams and removing Ground-types so that they can clean up with their deadly Rising Voltage later in the game.

Physically Defensive Pivot (Electric).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Fighting).description: Galarian Zapdos is an excellent Choice Scarf user on Fighting teams thanks to its unique set of traits within the type. Steel Wing notably OHKOes a huge threat to these teams in Mega Diancie while also nailing Tapu Lele and Alolan Ninetales. Knock Off targets Psychic- and Ghost-types like Galarian Slowking, Jirachi, and Galarian Corsola. Finally, U-turn can bring in teammates while getting chip damage on the foe as well as switching Galarian Zapdos out of bad matchups like Slowbro and Gholdengo. Iron Valiant equipped with Choice Specs or a Z-Crystal is able to break through Pokemon that wall Galarian Zapdos such as Kyurem, Latias, Raging Bolt, and Tapu Koko. Mega Gallade is another great teammate for Galarian Zapdos, as it acts as a great setup sweeper and wallbreaker with Swords Dance and greatly improves the Poison matchup. Iron Hands also pairs well, as it has a neutrality to Flying and can hit Flying-types with Ice Punch or Thunder Punch and has access to a slow Volt Switch that can bring it in safely. Iron Hands's great bulk also allows it to take on otherwise problematic threats like Enamorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Pelipper. Great Tusk is a nice support Pokemon for Galarian Zapdos, as it provides an Electric-immunity as well as Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock support, helping Galarian Zapdos get more KOs. It's also a great physical wall and can take out threats such as Iron Hands and Zeraora. In return, Galarian Zapdos handles Grass-types like Ogerpon-W, Tapu Bulu, and Mega Venusaur for it. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant can be a good team member for Galarian Zapdos, as it provides sleep support, taking counters to Galarian Zapdos out of the picture and easing the Water and Ground matchups. Hisuian Lilligant and Galarian Zapdos also make a great late-game cleaning duo.

Double Dance (Dark).description: With access to both Nasty Plot and Agility as well as a Special Attack-boosting ability in Berserk, Galarian Moltres is a great late-game sweeper for Dark teams. In addition, its part-Flying typing provides Dark teams with a great offensive option against Fighting and Bug teams, as well as a greatly appreciated neutrality to the aforementioned types. After one Nasty Plot boost, Galarian Moltres 2HKOes physically defensive Toxapex, physically defensive Ting-Lu, and Celesteela. After one Agility boost, it is able to outspeed would-be faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, Regieleki, and +1 Volcarona, as well as Mega Swampert in rain. With Flyinium Z , a Nasty Plot-boosted Supersonic Skystrike OHKOes Mega Diancie, Tapu Koko, and specially defensive Toxapex. An unboosted Supersonic Skystrike is still able to OHKO Terrakion after Stealth Rock damage. Hisuian Samurott provides entry hazard support in order to wear down incoming foes into OHKO range for Galarian Moltres, and in return, Galarian Moltres can threaten the Grass- and Fighting-types the two of them struggle with such as Mega Venusaur and Urshifu-R. Grimmsnarl is another great teammate, as it is able to set up dual screens to further make Galarian Moltres difficult to KO, and it can also run Taunt to prevent Stealth Rock from being set. Because of Galarian Moltres's part-Flying-typing, it is vulnerable to Stealth Rock. Because of this vulnerability, it appreciates hazard control from Mega Sableye's Magic Bounce, and Mega Sableye is also able to cripple opposing foes with Will-O-Wisp and Knock Off. Choice Band users such as Weavile, Roaring Moon, and Meowscarada can check walls Galarian Moltres struggles with like Dondozo and Clodsire. In return, Meowscarada and Weavile appreciate Galarian Moltres matching up well against Volcarona and Roaring Moon appreciates Galarian Moltres matching up well against Great Tusk. Lastly, Galarian Moltres can be paired with other sweepers such as Swords Dance Weavile and Dragon Dance Roaring Moon to soften each other's checks to enable each other to sweep. For example, Weavile is able to threaten Ting-Lu and Clodsire, while Galarian Moltres is able to handle Choice Scarf Gholdengo in return. When Galarian Moltres is not able to complete an outright sweep, it can set up for Choice Scarf users such as Meowscarada and Greninja to clean up.

Nasty Plot (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Dragon Dance (Flying).description: Dragonite makes for a great wallbreaker and late-game cleaner on Flying teams, outspeeding threats such as Zeraora and Mega Diancie after a Dragon Dance boost. Earthquake threatens Steel-, Poison-, and Rock-types like Gholdengo, Alolan Muk, and non-Choice Band Hisuian Arcanine. Roost grants Dragonite longevity as well as potentially reactivating Multiscale if its HP is restored to full. Substitute allows it to take advantage of passive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Will-O-Wisp Rotom-W, and Clodsire to set up Dragon Dance, but Roost is preferred since it grants Dragonite more opportunities to sweep. Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred so that Dragonite doesn't need to rely on entry hazard removal to switch in, while Leftovers grants it a form of longevity when it chooses to forego Roost. Mega Charizard Y is Dragonite's most important teammate, forming a great offensive pairing, with it threatening Ice-, Steel-, and Water-types such as Articuno, Alolan Ninetales, Corviknight, and Swampert, while Dragonite handles Galarian Slowking and Mega Charizard X. Corviknight and Celesteela deal with Fairy-, Ice-, and Rock-types such as Tapu Lele, Weavile, and Ogerpon-C; Corviknight also acts as a slow pivot to bring Dragonite in on Gholdengo. Choice Scarf Enamorus provides great speed control, outspeeding and threatening the likes of Mega Altaria and Iron Valiant while also dealing with Dark-types such as Mandibuzz and Mega Sableye. Additionally, Dragonite appreciates Healing Wish from Enamorus, as it can give Dragonite another opportunity to sweep. Thanks to Dragonite acting as a wallbreaker, it can enable fellow sweepers such as Mega Aerodactyl and Galarian Moltres. Mega Aerodactyl deals with Mega Lopunny and Articuno, while Galarian Moltres handles Tapu Bulu and Pecharunt.

Utility (Poison).description: Crobat finds a solid role on Poison teams thanks to its Ground immunity, high Speed, and solid utility movepool. Brave Bird deals with threats such as Iron Valiant, Mega Gallade, and Ogerpon-W. Infiltrator + Toxic is used to spread status against targets such as Substitute Hydreigon and Kyurem, while U-turn can be used to retain momentum against foes like Gholdengo. Defog provides longevity to teammates including Mega Venusaur and Alolan Muk by removing entry hazards so they can get the most out of their bulk. The EV spread allows Crobat to outspeed threats like Tornadus-T, Meowscarada, and Sneasler while still providing reasonable bulk, allowing it to take hits such as Freeze-Dry from Substitute Kyurem and +2 Dark Pulse from Hydreigon. Crobat greatly appreciates bulky teammates such as Toxapex and Mega Venusaur that can take Knock Off from the likes of Alolan Muk, Hisuian Goodra, and Ferrothorn, preventing it from losing its Heavy-Duty Boots. Mega Venusaur also complements Crobat by handling Ground-types such as Mega Swampert, Mamoswine, and Great Tusk. Alolan Muk provides a complementary Psychic immunity and can handle Psychic- and Ghost-type threats like Tapu Lele, Galarian Slowking, Blacephalon, and Gholdengo thanks to Knock Off and Pursuit. Nidoking can handle Electric-, Rock-, and Steel-type threats including Tapu Koko, Nihilego, Heatran, and Ferrothorn that can otherwise wall Crobat. Sneasler can similarly threaten Steel- and Rock-types threats like Hisuian Goodra, Tyranitar, and Ogerpon-C thanks to Close Combat, and it appreciates Crobat's ability to switch into bulky Ground-types like Clodsire and Hippowdon.

Z-Belly Drum (Fairy).description: Azumarill's presence is greatly appreciated on Fairy teams, where it tends to be the Z-Crystal user of choice and a good answer to the Fire, Ground, Rock, Poison and Steel matchups. Z-Belly Drum guarantees a +6 boost to Azumarill's already impressive Attack, turning it into a redoubtable setup sweeper with access to priority, and it can even offer a second setup opportunity if Azumarill gets forced out with its Z-Move unused. Aqua Jet is Azumarill's answer to threats that outspeed it, such as Volcarona, Tapu Koko, and Nidoking. Aside from dealing with Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Slowbro, and Sinistcha, Knock Off is Azumarill's best coverage option against walls that resist its other attacks, such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire. Breakneck Blitz coming off Return beats Mega Venusaur as well as Icium Z Toxapex, which doesn't fear Knock Off. Alternatively, Liquidation could be used as a stronger STAB option for slower foes like Iron Hands, Ting-Lu, and Celesteela, which is important if a Jolly nature is used. Ice Spinner is an alternative that can be used to defeat both Ting-Lu and Mega Venusaur after some chip, along with getting rid of Psychic Terrain to allow for Aqua Jet to be used without being blocked. Klefki is an amazing partner for Azumarill, offering a Poison immunity and dual screens support to ease setup and spreading Spikes to chip the opposing team. Mega Diancie helps in the Fire and Flying matchups and provides entry hazard control, contributing to keeping Azumarill healthy as well as providing Stealth Rock to help its wallbreaking. Tapu Koko deals with Water-types such as Pelipper and Toxapex, making Azumarill's sweep easier down the line, and it also handles Steel- and Flying-types like Celesteela and Corviknight should Azumarill opt for Return. Tapu Bulu also aids in the Water and Electric matchup, handling foes like Quagsire and Rotom-W that Azumarill can struggle to bring down. Iron Valiant deals with most Fighting-types and, when paired with Tapu Koko, outspeeds and defeats faster foes such as Mega Lopunny and Mega Swampert under rain, but it competes with Azumarill for a Z-Crystal. Tapu Lele handles Poison-types like Mega Venusaur and Clodsire, but be cautious of Psychic Terrain preventing Azumarill from using Aqua Jet. Babiri Berry Clefable can be used as an alternative to Tapu Lele for checking Scizor, and it also handles Mega Venusaur well, as it can use it as setup fodder.

Specially Defensive (Water).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Assault Vest (Poison).description: Assault Vest Galarian Slowking acts as Poison teams' specially defensive Regenerator wall,easily taking on threats like Choice Specs Latios and Zapdos. Future Sight is used to deal solid damage and create traps that physically attacking teammates such as Sneasler and Okidogi can make use of to break walls such as Blissey and Mega Venusaur, which would otherwise only take Future Sight or the physical hit. Ice Beam hits Flying-types like Enamorus, Zapdos, Landorus, and Thundurus-T. Flamethrower can be run over Sludge Bomb or Ice Beam and can threaten Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Celesteela. Finally, Earthquake beats Heatran, which can be problematic for Poison teams, but should only be used if Galarian Slowking is already running Flamethrower. The given EV spread lets it survive Choice Specs Psyshock from Tapu Lele after Stealth Rock damage. Sneasler and Okidogi pair excellently with Galarian Slowking, using their Fighting-type STAB moves to threaten Dark-types like Hydreigon and Ting-Lu along with specially defensive targets such as Hisuian Goodra and Blissey. They also majorly appreciate Galarian Slowking's Future Sight helping form a devastating combination that can break past physical walls like Mega Venusaur and Great Tusk with ease. Sneasler also appreciates Galarian Slowking as a safe target to pivot into with U-turn against special attackers like Thundurus-T. Alolan Muk complements Galarian Slowking by threatening Ghost-types such as Blacephalon and Gholdengo along with serving as a safe switch-in against Psychic-types like Tapu Lele, which can otherwise break past Galarian Slowking with Psyshock. Crobat provides a solid Ground Immunity and entry hazard removal in Defog, and it also helps deal with foes like Ogerpon-W and Mega Gallade that threaten Galarian Slowking. Mega Venusaur helps by removing problematic Ground- and Water-types like Mamoswine and Dondozo.

Specially Defensive (Psychic).description:
Galarian Slowking finds a niche on Psychic teams thanks to its incredible solid Special Defense and strong support moves such as Toxic Spikes. Sludge Bomb can spread Poison along with dealing with Fairy-type threats like Primarina and Enamorus. Ice Beam deals with Flying- and Dragon-type threats such as Zapdos, Tornadus-T, Latios, and Raging Bolt. Chilly Reception allows Galarian Slowking to safely pivot into its teammates. Finally, Thunder Wave slows down faster targets such as Volcarona and Greninja, allowing a teammate to comfortably remove them. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Galarian Slowking to safely come in; however, Black Sludge can be used to gain passive recovery.

Slowbro is a solid partner for Galarian Slowking, providing a Regenerator core for Psychic teams, with Slowbro being able to take on physical threats like Great Tusk, Barraskewda, and Cinderace, which threaten Galarian Slowking, while Galarian Slowking handles foes such as Primarina and Zapdos. Latios and Iron Boulder appreciate Galarian Slowking's Chilly Reception to safely pivot them in against threats like Kyurem and Iron Moth. Meanwhile, Galarian Slowking appreciates Latios removing threats such as Landorus, Gouging Fire, and Overqwil, along with Choice Scarf Iron Boulder emoving threats like Flutter Mane, Volcarona, and Tyranitar. Hoopa-U is appreciated for its ability to handle Ghost-type threats like Gholdengo, Spectrier, and Hisuian Zoroark and can use Knock Off to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes like Blissey to make Galarian Slowking's Toxic Spikes more potent. Galarian Slowking appreciates Hatterene's ability to block entry hazards along with its ability to take on Dark-type threats such as Hydreigon and Hisuian Samurott.

Entry Hazard Support (Bug).description:
Counter lets Forretress deal with physical threats like Gouging Fire and Mega Aerodactyl which otherwise decimates Bug teams.

Curse (Ground).description:
An Impish nature lets Mega Steelix survive Azumarill's Aqua Jet after it has used Belly Drum.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Swords Dance (Steel).description: Mega Scizor makes for a strong wallbreaker and sweeper on Steel teams thanks to its access to Swords Dance, high Attack stat, and well-rounded bulk. Bullet Punch is Mega Scizor's strongest STAB move, and its priority allows it to revenge kill faster threats such as Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny. Close Combat is Mega Scizor's strongest coverage move, enabling it to more easily beat Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. After a Swords Dance boost, Mega Scizor becomes strong enough to 2HKO Celesteela, opposing Mega Scizor, and physically defensive Gastrodon. Knock Off removes essential items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Tornadus-T and Black Sludge from Toxapex, and it also provides Mega Scizor with strong coverage against Aegislash, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo. Alternatively, Trailblaze can also be used to 2HKO bulky Water- or Ground-type Pokemon most other Steel-types struggle with such as Mega Swampert and Gastrodon, as well as potentially OHKO Azumarill and Rotom-W after a Swords Dance boost and Stealth Rock damage. 132 Speed EVs are invested in order for Mega Scizor to outspeed Jolly Azumarill as well as Hydreigon and Urshifu-S after a Trailblaze. Heatran and Ferrothorn are great teammates because they are able to set entry hazards to wear down incoming foes, and Heatran also has the added benefit of providing a Fire immunity thanks to its ability. Ferrothorn can also provide passive healing for Mega Scizor via the use of Leech Seed. In return, Mega Scizor is able to threaten faster Fighting-types such as Sneasler and Iron Valiant with Bullet Punch. Gholdengo is able to threaten Toxapex and Tapu Lele, and it along with Aegislash can also hinder foes with Toxic and Thunder Wave respectively if they are running defensive sets, easing set up for Mega Scizor. In return, Mega Scizor can remove Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Ting-Lu, and Galarian Moltres. Specially defensive Celesteela is an excellent special wall that can wall Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Mega Altaria, while also being able to spread status and use Leech Seed to aid Mega Scizor in its sweeping. As Mega Scizor is more vulnerable to hazards compared to other Steel-types, it appreciates hazard removal from the likes of Corviknight, Excadrill, and Iron Treads. Excadrill and Iron Treads also have the added merit of handling Fire-types like Victini and Ogerpon-H. Excadrill can also bypass Mega Sableye's Magic Bounce and inflict poison on it thanks to Mold Breaker, while Iron Treads can threaten both Landorus formes with Ice Spinner.

Bulky Swords Dance (Steel).description: Mega Scizor's neutrality to Ground and Fighting and role compression as a wall and sweeper make it a formidable asset for Steel teams. Knock Off hinders predicted checks that Mega Scizor lures in on the switch such as Celesteela, Porygon2, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W, notably removing Heavy-Duty Boots to enable entry hazards that are characteristic of Steel teams. The first EV spread with an Adamant nature maximizes damage output, notably OHKOing Hisuian Lilligant, Meowscarada, and Kyurem with +2 Bullet Punch; it also outspeeds Adamant Azumarill and has the rest invested in HP to optimize mixed bulk. The second EV spread with an Impish nature also outspeeds Adamant Azumarill and avoids a 2HKO after Stealth Rock from Mega Lopunny's Close Combat and Adamant Mega Swampert's Earthquake, yet requires a layer of Spikes to OHKO Hisuian Lilligant and Meowscarada with +2 Bullet Punch. Mega Scizor is extremely vulnerable to Fire-type moves, so Heatran is a solid partner to mitigate this weakness. As Mega Scizor can often have a difficult time sweeping because Bullet Punch is easy to resist, Excadrill and Iron Treads make an offensive core with Mega Scizor, as they can pressure the Fire-, Electric- and Steel-types that would check it; notably, the former can additionally handle Rotom-W and the latter offensively checks Landorus. Ferrothorn and Hisuian Goodra are also options to further complement and handle Water-types for it. Gholdengo can wear down the opposing team as it stallbreaks past foes such as Toxapex, Mega Sableye, and Hisuian Goodra, easing Mega Scizor's sweep late-game; it also acts as an additional check for Fighting-types Mega Scizor can't consistently switch into such as Iron Valiant. Corviknight can remove entry hazards, increasing the longevity of Mega Scizor and the rest of its team, as well as pivot to it with U-turn to ease switching. Skarmory is also an alternative that can set Spikes, letting Mega Scizor reach OHKOes that it wouldn't otherwise.

Choice Band (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Sticky Web (Rock).description: Shuckle is an essential member of any hyper offensive Rock team due to its access to Sticky Web, which allows teammates such as Mega Diancie and Terrakion to dominate the Steel and Dark matchups. With Mental Herb, it isn't scared to set up entry hazards in front of common Taunt users such as Deoxys-S and Zeraora. Encore shuts down setup sweepers such as Mega Scizor and bulky walls such as Hippowdon and Ferrothorn, locking them into their setup and recovery moves. Shuckle can generate momentum after setting up hazards by using Final Gambit, allowing teammates such as Shell Smash Omastar, Mega Diancie, and Choice Band Tyranitar to come in and start exerting pressure. Toxic can also be used to punish more passive Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Hippowdon. Mega Diancie can bounce back any hazards or status moves directed at Shuckle and provides amazing offensive pressure and coverage against Poison-, Steel-, and Dragon-types. Sticky Web allows Choice Band Tyranitar to outspeed Choice Specs Gholdengo and Nidoking, both of which are threats to Rock. Omastar and Minior benefit from Stealth Rock breaking potential Focus Sashes and are great partners to have in the Grass and Fighting matchups. Thanks to Sticky Web, Omastar outspeeds Sand Rush Excadrill after one shell smash and +1 Spe Nihilego outspeeds Barraskewda in the rain. Power Herb Nihilego is able to sweep teams as well with Meteor Beam and amazing coverage. Thanks to Sticky Web, Choice Scarf Terrakion outspeeds Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Greninja, which are threats to Rock teams. Hisuian Arcanine is able to deal massive damage, OHKOing Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Heatran, Mega Gallade, and Corviknight after Stealth Rock.

Specially Defensive Wall (Ice).description: Piloswine is one of Ice teams' best specially defensive walls, capable of filling some of Ice teams' biggest roles of being an entry hazard setter and Electric immunity. Thick Fat coupled with Eviolite gives Piloswine tremendous bulk, with which it can check dangerous Fire-type threats to Ice such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y by disposing of them with Rock Slide. 12 EVs in Attack guarantees an OHKO on offensive Volcarona. Another one of Piloswine's amazing traits is its Ground typing, which makes it a great asset in the Electric matchup by preventing a Volt Switch onslaught while also letting it hit Electric-types super effectively with STAB Earthquake. Toxic is an option to put defensive switch-ins such as Skeledirge and Rotom-W on a timer, helping Piloswine's teammates overpower them, but Roar is an alternative choice to force out threats that may use it to set up, such as Mega Scizor, and to rack up hazard damage from its Stealth Rock and Cloyster's Spikes to wear down threats such as Urshifu-R and Mega Venusaur. Piloswine appreciates Alolan Ninetales's snow and Aurora Veil, which let it wall the opposition more easily. Piloswine is, however, extremely vulnerable to Water-types, so partnering it with Kyurem or Arctozolt is appreciated, as they can easily break Water teams. Substitute Baxcalibur also threatens Poison teams, which can cripple Piloswine with Toxic. Weavile with a Z-Crystal is also a good Knock Off absorber for Piloswine, as losing Eviolite ruins Piloswine; Weavile also forces immense progress by removing key items from Celesteela and Skeledirge, which become susceptible to Stealth Rock afterwards, or outright breaking through them with a Z-Move. Galarian Darmanitan and Shell Smash Cloyster can threaten Steel teams with Flare Blitz and Hydro Pump or Hidden Power Fire, respectively. The Stealth Rocks and Toxic spread by Piloswine also accentuates the breaking power of teammates such as Swords Dance or Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Belly Drum Cetitan. IronPress Avalugg and defensive Cloyster with Hidden Power Fire are also good partners in being able to shut down Mega Scizor. Avalugg, Articuno, and Cloyster are also capable of removing entry hazards, with the latter two also being able to pivot in Piloswine with U-turn and Teleport, respectively.

Water Absorb (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

IronPress (Steel).description: Providing a neutrality to Fighting and a immunity to Ground, Skarmory is a valuable option for Steel teams to mitigate their most common weaknesses and set entry hazards. Its IronPress combination enables Skarmory to act as a win condition, notably using foes such as Tapu Bulu, Mega Aerodactyl, and Excadrill as setup fodder. As Skarmory is passive against Ghost-types, Gholdengo is a solid partner, as it can apply offensive pressure against them and also keeps entry hazards set by Skarmory on the field to ease wearing down the opposing team. Heatran's high special bulk and Fire immunity support Skarmory by acting as a switch-in to foes that can easily overwhelm Skarmory such as Mega Latias, Volcarona, and Mega Pidgeot. Defensive Electric-resistant teammates such as Ferrothorn can switch into Electric-types that threaten Skarmory such as Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Zapdos; Ferrothorn also makes a hazard stacking core with it. Archaludon similarly checks Electric-types that threaten Skarmory and handles physical attackers Skarmory can't properly handle such as Ceruledge, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Charizard X. Iron Treads offensively checks Electric-types, as well as some foes Skarmory has trouble against such as Landorus and Gholdengo.

Swift Swim (Water).description:
A Timid nature outspeeds Choice Scarf Roaring Moon.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

The Duck.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Specially Defensive.description: Blissey's high Special Defense stat is pivotal to its role as a wall. In addition to its great bulk, it gets access to great utility moves such as Teleport for momentum, Soft-Boiled for reliable recovery and longevity, Toxic to cripple foes, and Stealth Rock to put pressure on Mega Charizard X and Choice Scarf Cinderace. Seismic Toss additionally provides a consistent damaging move to chip incoming Pokemon without the means to recover and deal with special attackers such as Greninja and Landorus by taking hits. Blissey runs Heavy-Duty Boots to prevent passive chip from entry hazards to help it create momentum for its teammates. Staraptor pairs well with Blissey as part of Normal's defensive core with access to Intimidate and ability to take hits from threats such as Great Tusk and physically offensive Iron Valiant. It can also use Defog to remove hazards if Blissey's Heavy-Duty Boots have been removed by Knock Off. Since Blissey is able to take hits from Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Blacephalon, it can freely switch into them and then use Teleport to bring in one of Normal's offensive threats such as Ursaluna, Terapagos, or Mega Lopunny. Ursaluna and Mega Lopunny provide Normal with physical wallbreaking capabilities, while Calm Mind Terapagos can be used as a special wallbreaker. Terapagos can also be used as a bulkier presence to remove hazards with Rapid Spin and poison foes with Toxic. Hisuian Zoroark allows for mind games to be played, as its secondary typing provides an immunity to Fighting. In addition, it is able to disguise itself as a more passive Pokemon such as Blissey to provide a false sense of security to the opponent. Ditto provides a counter to setup Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Ceruledge, being able to transform into them and outspeeding them while also potentially reverse sweeping the opponent's team. Mega Pidgeot provides strong Flying-type coverage with Hurricane against Fighting-types such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Kommo-o.

Choice Band (Rock).description: Choice Band Tyranitar is the premier physical wallbreaker on Rock teams with its massive base 134 Attack stat and its access to Pursuit allowing it to revenge kill Gholdengo, Latias, and Hisuian Zoroark. Stone Edge deals huge damage to key Pokemon that Rock-types struggle with such as Corviknight, Celesteela, and Mega Venusaur. Knock Off means that Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Slowbro have to be careful when facing Tyranitar, along with removing valuable items from Toxapex and Empoleon. Fire Punch OHKOes the likes of Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn, both of which are threats to Rock teams. Earthquake helps with the Steel, Poison, and Rock mirror matchups by hitting Heatran, Clodsire, and Garganacl with a lot of power. Heavy Slam is also worth mentioning, as it can OHKO the likes of Tapu Bulu and Clefable and helps the Fairy matchup a tremendous amount. Ice Punch is an alternative as well, as it threatens to OHKO foes such as Landorus and Gliscor. Additionally, Tyranitar is able to set up sand, aiding teammates such as Garganacl, Cradilly, and Nihilego with a Special Defense boost. A Jolly nature allows Tyranitar to outspeed Choice Specs Iron Valiant outside of Electric Terrain and Mega Diancie while Sticky Web is up and OHKO both with Heavy Slam. This does, however, cause a loss of power, making the Steel and Poison matchups much harder by not 2HKOing Corviknight and Mega Venusaur with Stone Edge. Shuckle can set up Sticky Web, which allows Tyranitar to outspeed threats such as Gholdengo and Nidoking. Mega Diancie is a great special wallbreaker that Tyranitar needs on its team to deal with the Fighting-types that threaten it such as Kommo-o and Great Tusk. Cradily gives Tyranitar a switch-in to Ground-type moves that can reliably take hits and proceed to use Recover to maintain its health while also setting up Stealth Rock. Choice Scarf Terrakion pairs amazingly with Tyranitar by taking the physical wallbreaking load off of Tyranitar and splitting it between the two powerhouses. Terrakion is able to revenge kill Mega Lopunny while also benefitting from Tyranitar's Pursuit trapping ability. As a wall, Garganacl appreciates Tyranitar removing Leftovers from Pokemon such as Hippowdon and Ting-Lu. Ogerpon-C creates additional pressure in the Ground and Water matchups, complementing Tyranitar's power with great coverage. Nihilego helps with Tyranitar's weakness to Fairy-types, providing great Special Defense in sand, as well as Poison coverage. Although Tyranitar has great bulk, Rhyperior and Omastar are better checks to Scizor, a huge threat to the Rock type. Rhyperior's great bulk and ability allow it to beat Scizor, while Omastar's neutrality to Steel-type moves allows it to beat Scizor one-on-one.

Nasty Plot (Grass).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Rain Sweeper (Water).description: Mega Swampert is a mainstay on rain-based Water teams due to its ability Swift Swim, part-Ground typing, great role compression, and fearsome wallbreaking ability, heavily improving the Electric, Poison, and Dragon matchups. Earthquake nails Water-resistant foes like Toxapex, Hisuian Goodra, and Water Absorb Clodsire as well as Electric-types such as Tapu Koko, Iron Hands, and Zeraora. Furthermore, with sufficient chip damage, it's capable of overwhelming Ferrothorn and Gastrodon. Waterfall is nicely complemented by rain as it outdamages Ice Punch when combatting Flying-types like Zapdos and Corviknight. Waterfall is notably preferred over Liquidation due to its higher PP and potential to break through walls, such as the aforementioned Corviknight, via flinching. Ice Punch targets Dragon- and Grass-types like Dragonite, Latias, and Tapu Bulu due to their resistances to Mega Swampert's STAB combination. Flip Turn allows Mega Swampert to escape unfavorable situations and form pivoting cores with teammates like Pelipper, Greninja, and Barraskewda. Alternatively, Stealth Rock may be used to take advantage of Mega Swampert's ability to force switches, while other options such as Stone Edge and Toxic may be used to threaten Mantine, Pelipper, and Rotom-W which wall it otherwise. A Jolly nature is preferred to outpace Choice Scarf Thundurus-T, Volcarona after one Quiver Dance, and opposing Mega Swampert. However, an Adamant nature may be used for higher damage rolls against Kommo-o, Mega Venusaur, and Gastrodon. Pelipper is a perfect teammate, as it provides rain with Drizzle, slowly pivots into Mega Swampert with U-turn, and removes entry hazards with Defog. In return, Mega Swampert provides an immunity against the aforementioned Electric-type moves and threatens Rock-types such as Terrakion and Mega Diancie. Toxapex provides a buffer against Grass-types like Rillaboom and Meowscarada as well as Kommo-o while also providing Toxic Spikes to enhance Mega Swampert's wallbreaking capabilities. Furthermore, Toxapex appreciates Mega Swampert forcing out Heatran and Gholdengo, as they easily take advantage of Toxapex's passivity. Urshifu-R and Barraskewda deal with threats like Ferrothorn, Hydreigon, and Kyurem, while Mega Swampert removes Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire. Other Swift Swim users like Basculegion-F and Barraskewda take on threats like Slowbro and Tapu Koko outside of rain, respectively. Greninja provides speed control outside of rain and beats Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu and Alolan Ninetales with Gunk Shot as well as overloads shared Water-resistant foes like Ferrothorn and Mega Venusaur with a Choice Specs set. Empoleon is a good teammate as it can free up Mega Swampert's Stealth Rock moveslot and switch into Freeze-Dry users like Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales.

Specially Defensive (Water).description: Swampert provides great defensive coverage for Water teams thanks to its crucial immunity to Electric, as well as support with Stealth Rock and Flip Turn. Roar allows Swampert to phaze out setup sweepers that it can take hits from such as Mega Charizard X and Galarian Moltres; notably, the both of them are especially vulnerable to Stealth Rock due to their lack of recovery. Flip Turn allows Swampert to take advantage of its low Speed to bring in a teammate safely. Greninja serves as a great partner, as not only can it threaten Grass-types such as Mega Venusaur, Sinistcha, and Ogerpon-W, but it also takes on a myriad of threats like Great Tusk, Mega Latias, and Slowbro with its coverage. Toxapex forms a defensive partnership with Swampert, as it can stack hazards with Toxic Spikes as well as take on Grass- and Fairy-types such as Meowscarada, Tapu Bulu, and Azumarill, while Swampert can switch into a predicted Electric-type attack from Regieleki and Mangezone. Ogerpon-W appreciates Swampert taking on Poison-types it dislikes like Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire, and in return, it eases the Ground matchup by taking out the Landorus formes and Excadrill. Pelipper provides a Ground immunity, and it takes on Fighting-types like Buzzwole and Keldeo; Barraskewda can also be used alongside Pelipper so that rain teams can opt to use this version over Mega Swampert instead. Hisuian Samurott can also stack entry hazards with Ceaseless Edge, and it assists in the Ghost matchup by taking on the likes of Sinistcha and non-Choice Scarf Gholdengo. Keldeo and Urshifu-R deal with Kyurem, which can remove Swampert with Freeze-Dry.

Rain Setter (Water).description: Pelipper is one of Water's most valuable Pokemon thanks to its ability to set up rain to activate Swift Swim for its teammates and its various utility options. Hurricane under rain is able to consistently hit Grass- and Fighting-types like Mega Venusaur and Ogerpon-W. Alternatively, Scald punishes switch-ins like Iron Hands and Zeraora with a potential bur, and it also targets Hippowdon. U-turn in tandem with its low Speed allows Pelipper to bring in its teammates safely. With 9 Speed IVs, Pelipper underspeeds Hippowdon, guaranteeing it sets up rain after Hippowdon's sand. Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Kingdra appreciate Pelipper's rain, as it activates their Swift Swim to outspeed and threaten Tapu Koko, Alolan Raichu, and Mega Latias, respectively. Ogerpon-W is another beneficiary of rain, as it further boosts the power of Ivy Cudgel. Notably, Ivy Cudgel now outright OHKOes Thundurus-T, has a high chance of OHKOing Alolan Muk after Stealth Rock damage, and guarantees a 2HKO on Galarian Weezing when unboosted. Urshifu-R and Keldeo can deal with Kyurem and bulky Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Empoleon. Toxapex sets up Toxic Spikes or spreads poison directly with Toxic to aid Pelipper's teammates; it is also great in the Fairy matchup, handling the likes of Tapu Bulu, Tapu Fini, and Azumarill.

Dual Status User (Ghost).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Mixed Wall (Dark).description: Mega Sableye is a relevant defensive backbone for Dark teams because it serves as a switch-in to Fighting-type moves and is a good punisher of entry hazard setters such as Archaludon, Klefki, and Clodsire thanks to its solid mixed bulk and Magic Bounce. Metal Burst lets Mega Sableye reduce its passivity by damaging foes more than Knock Off, notably OHKOing Kommo-o after withstanding Clangorous Soulblaze and Mega Diancie. Protect is an alternative that lets it safely Mega Evolve when it's threatened by foes such as Mega Diancie and Mega Lopunny, ensuring that it can block entry hazards mid-game with Magic Bounce and easing its prediction against Choice-locked foes such as Galarian Darmanitan and Enamorus. The given EV spread allows Mega Sableye to avoid an OHKO from Mega Diancie's Moonblast and a 2HKO from Excadrill's Earthquake. Mega Sableye is forced out by Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant and Tapu Koko, so Alolan Muk and Ting-Lu are good partners to mitigate this weakness; the latter also sets hazards up, which Mega Sableye can maintain by blocking Rapid Spin from Excadrill, Iron Treads, and Terapagos. Mandibuzz complements Mega Sableye by checking Fighting-types it can't consistently handle such as Mega Lopunny and Great Tusk and providing hazard control as further backup if Mega Sableye is unable to keep entry hazards off of its side of the field. As Mega Sableye cripples foes throughout a battle, setup sweepers such as Hydreigon and Weavile and cleaners like Choice Scarf Meowscarada find easier setup opportunities to KO foes on the other team.

Mixed Wall (Ghost).description: Mega Sableye is a staple on bulkier Ghost teams due to its Dark typing, great abilities before and after Mega Evolution, and great defensive stats. Knock Off hinders Chansey and Porygon2 for Mega Sableye's wallbreaking teammates and eases the matchup against Landorus and Nidoking. Due to Sableye's meager HP and need for longevity, Recover's a must-have utility option, further enabling Metal Burst. Protect allows Sableye to Mega Evolve safely, ensuring it can utilize Magic Bounce later into the game. Metal Burst retaliates against Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie, while Dazzling Gleam eliminates Mega Sableye's passivity in front of Hydreigon and Roaring Moon. Will-O-Wisp in conjunction with Prankster renders physical attackers like Mega Gallade, Dragonite, and Mamoswine less threatening. The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Nidoking's Earth Power, assuming Mega Sableye uses Knock Off after the first Earth Power. Mimikyu threatens Dark-types such as Mandibuzz, Galarian Moltres, and opposing Mega Sableye. Gholdengo checks Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant as well as preventing foes from removing entry hazards set by Froslass and Galarian Corsola. Blacephalon handles opposing Gholdengo and utilizes Choice Scarf to clean through Steel, Ghost, and Psychic teams once Heatran, Mega Sableye, and Galarian Slowking, respectively, are removed. Skeledirge has great synergy with Mega Sableye, appreciating the prevention of opposing Stealth Rock and in return walling Volcarona, Mega Lopunny, and Alolan Ninetales.

Sun Setter.description: Torkoal provides great support for Fire teams thanks to its ability to set sun and Stealth Rock as well as remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Lava Plume can potentially burn offensive threats like Dragonite and Iron Hands. Body Press allows Torkoal to use its great physical bulk to its advantage by threatening Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Tyranitar. Heat Rock allows Torkoal's sun to support teammates for longer, but Heavy-Duty Boots can also be used so that Torkoal can switch in more freely without fearing entry hazards and have an easier time removing them. Yawn is an option that pairs well with Stealth Rock because it forces switches. Volcarona makes for a great partner, as it appreciates the sun Torkoal sets so that its Flamethrower can hit new benchmarks, notably OHKOing Landorus and 2HKOing Empoleon and Alolan Muk after a boost, as well as now being able to survive a Hydro Pump from Choice Specs Greninja to set up one Quiver Dance. In return, Volcarona is able to deal with Fighting- and Ground-types such as Kommo-o, Swampert, and Great Tusk thanks to its coverage. Cinderace threatens Normal- and Rock-type foes such as Porygon2, Ogerpon-C, and Hisuian Arcanine and can don a Choice Scarf to dispatch speedy threats such as Choice Scarf Iron Treads and Tapu Lele. Heatran deals with problematic walls such as Toxapex and Archaludon by trapping them with Magma Storm and removing them with Earth Power as well as Diancie with Flash Cannon. Heatran also runs Stealth Rock so that Torkoal can opt to use another option such as Yawn. Late-game sweepers and cleaners such as Mega Charizard X, Ceruledge, and Blacephalon appreciate the sun Torkoal provides so that they can mop up more efficiently.

Offensive Dragon Dance (Dragon).description: Mega Altaria's unique typing and offensive potential allow it to serve as a valuable setup sweeper that checks threats like Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Iron Hands, and Keldeo. Pixilate-boosted Return checks the aforementioned Dragon-types as well as Fighting- and Dark-types such as Terrakion, Mega Sableye, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is essential coverage, as it hits Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Magnezone and—in conjunction with Return—eases the Dark and Electric matchups. Roost increases Mega Altaria's longevity so it can continuously Dragon Dance throughout the match or use its bulk to switch into threats. The given EV spread allows Mega Altaria to survive Mega Lopunny's Triple Axel. Choice Specs Kyurem is a great teammate, as it breaks past the likes of Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo for Mega Altaria. Garchomp sets up Stealth Rock and Spikes, wearing down Mega Altaria's switch-ins. Kommo-o breaks past Steel-types like Skarmory, Aegislash, and defensive Celesteela as well as other troublesome walls like Toxapex and Hippowdon for Mega Altaria. Roaring Moon threatens obstacles such as Mega Diancie, Choice Specs Greninja, and Skeledirge.

Calm Mind (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: Choice Scarf Latias is an effective form of speed control on Psychic teams, differentiating itself from other Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele and Iron Boulder with its excellent utility options such as Healing Wish. Latias's part-Dragon typing alongside Levitate lets it switch into and threaten many Electric- and Ground-type attackers such as Alolan Raichu and Landorus. Trick is preferred over Defog, as it allows Latias to shift its Choice Scarf to special walls like Ting-Lu and Blissey that would otherwise trouble it. However, Defog can be used over Trick to allow it to clear entry hazards for its teammates thanks to its great Speed. Healing Wish lets Latias stand out from other Choice Scarf users by allowing it to give one of its teammates a second chance in battle. Victini is a fantastic teammate for Latias because it that helps break through Steel-type Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Skarmory. Similarly, Mega Gallade can support Latias by breaking down Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Heatran, Hisuian Goodra, Tyranitar, and Ting-Lu. In return, Latias can provide Healing Wish and Defog support for both Mega Gallade and Victini, check Zapdos for Mega Gallade, and check Ground- and Water-type Pokemon such as Garchomp and Ogerpon-W for Victini. Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is an excellent teammate for Latias, threatening Dark-type Pokemon such as Mega Sableye and Weavile. Jirachi is also a great teammate because it can deal with Fairy-type Pokemon such as Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, sponge attacks from Pokemon like Kyurem and opposing Latias, set up entry hazards, and provide safe switch-ins for Latias with U-turn.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: Choice Scarf Latias is a premier revenge killer on Dragon teams for its decent revenge killing capabilities, as it's able to outspeed common threats to Dragon teams such as Iron Valiant, Choice Specs Greninja, and Mega Garchomp while providing useful utility options in Defog and Healing Wish. Psychic lets Latias revenge kill troublesome Fighting-type Pokemon such as Hisuian Lilligant and Mega Lopunny. However, Psyshock can instead be used to hit Assault Vest Iron Hands and Clodsire harder. Defog allows Latias to work as emergency entry hazard removal thanks to its great Speed. Trick can be used over Defog to allow Latias to cripple special walls like Galarian Slowking and Blissey. Healing Wish lets Latias restore the health and status of one of its teammates, allowing them to have a second chance in the battle. Mega Altaria and Roaring Moon are superb partners that threaten the Dark- and Ghost-type Pokemon that Latias is weak to such as Tyranitar and Gholdengo. Kyurem is another great offensive partner, as it can destroy threats that Latias struggles against such as Mamoswine and Ting-Lu; in return, Latias can inconvenience special walls like Blissey and Galarian Slowking with Trick, beat Fighting-type Pokemon such as Keldeo and Urshifu-R for Kyurem, and provide Healing Wish support for it to take advantage of. Garchomp is also a great partner that pressures Steel-type Pokemon that Latias struggles against. It can also punish most physical attacks directed at Latias with Rough Skin if using a defensive set, while its Swords Dance set takes advantage of special walls that Latias struggles with such as Blissey and Galarian Slowking. Garchomp can also set up hazards, which allow Latias to OHKO threats such as Greninja for its team. Kommo-o is also a fantastic partner for Latias, as it beats Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Mega Scizor and Ting-Lu while also appreciating Healing Wish support for a second assault. Archaludon is a great partner for Latias as well, as it provides a buffer against threats such as Roaring Moon and Mega Altaria that would otherwise beat Latias or take advantage of it while also setting up hazards for Latias.

20 Spe EVs lets it outspeed Breloom and Pokemon around that speed tier

Specially Defensive (Water).description: Empoleon is one of Water's best options for role compression thanks to its wide array of utility options. Furthermore, its great special bulk coupled with a great defensive typing allows it to easily shrug off hits from some of the biggest threats to Water teams such as Tapu Lele and Kyurem. Defog removes entry hazards, allowing its teammates to switch in more safely, and it also removes opponents' dual screens to ease the Fairy matchup. Alternatively, Empoleon can run Stealth Rock to wear down foes over time to aid its offensive partners. Flash Cannon targets Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Lele. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types like Hisuian Zoroark and Jirachi while removing items from foes that rely on them like Rotom-W and Corviknight. Alternatively, Flip Turn allows Empoleon to take advantage of its low Speed by acting as a slow pivot to bring its teammates in safely. Pelipper pairs well with Empoleon, as the two of them form a pivoting core, and it appreciates Empoleon taking on Tapu Lele and Kyurem. In return, Pelipper can run Defog so that Empoleon can choose to run Stealth Rock instead. Rain-boosted sweepers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda appreciate Empoleon taking on Kyurem's Freeze-Dry and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, respectively, and in return, it provides an Electric immunity and can sweep under rain. Urshifu-R and Keldeo appreciate Empoleon setting up Stealth Rock and challenging Fairy-types; in return, the two of them challenge Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Hisuian Goodra. Choice Specs Greninja, with its great coverage, handles a myriad of threats to Empoleon such as non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, Great Tusk, and the Landorus formes, and it appreciates Defog and Stealth Rock support in return. Choice Scarf Hisuian Samurott can stack Spikes with Ceaseless Edge, and it takes on Ghost- and Psychic-types if Empoleon forgoes Knock Off. Ogerpon-W's Ground-resistant typing allows it to deal with the likes of the Landorus formes, Great Tusk, and Mamoswine in the Ground matchup.

Physically Defensive (Normal).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Physically Defensive (Ground).description: Gastrodon is a mainstay on Ground teams due to its vast utility options, great bulk along with reliable recovery, and a stellar ability in Storm Drain, checking a myriad of Water-types like Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Keldeo. Scald threatens physical attackers such as Dragonite, Mega Lopunny, and Mimikyu with a burn. Thanks to Gastrodon's bulk, it is able to stack multiple layers of Spikes to wear down opposing teams. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used, freeing a moveslot from a teammate such as Garchomp or Hippowdon. Toxic puts troublesome walls such as Mantine, Ting-Lu, and Araquanid on a timer. Earthquake may be used alongside a Relaxed nature to break Calm Mind Keldeo's Substitute. All of Gastrodon's teammates appreciate its ability to switch into Water-type attacks. Unaware Clodsire checks Grass-types such as Meowscarada and Tapu Bulu as well as setup sweepers Gastrodon can't beat like Volcarona and Galarian Moltres. Iron Treads removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin so Gastrodon can better perform its defensive duties. Wallbreakers like Landorus and Great Tusk appreciate Gastrodon's entry hazard support so that they can net more damage. Mamoswine acts as a secondary Ice-type switch-in that checks the likes of SubRoost Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales, relieving pressure off of Gastrodon.

All-Out Attacker.description: Mega Lopunny is the best Mega Evolution available for Normal teams due to its blistering Speed tier, great offensive prowess, and unique ability in Scrappy. Fake Out lets Mega Lopunny serve as an exceptional revenge killer, dealing with worn down foes like Meowscarada, Barraskewda, and Alolan Raichu. It also puts Pokemon like Keldeo, Cinderace, and Tapu Koko in range of its other attacks safely. With Scrappy, Close Combat notably lets Mega Lopunny take on threats like Mega Sableye, Aegislash, and Gholdengo, threatening the defensive cores of Dark and Steel teams. U-turn enables Mega Lopunny to work as a potent offensive pivot, escaping unfavorable situations against walls like Slowbro and Mega Venusaur while keeping momentum. Triple Axel threatens common switch-ins such as Gliscor and Mandibuzz, while Return is Mega Lopunny's hardest-hitting move against most Psychic- and Fairy-types, such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Blissey is a great teammate, taking on the likes of Volcarona and Zapdos thanks to its bulk while offering support in the form of Stealth Rock, Toxic, and Teleport. Staraptor switches into Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Tapu Bulu, and its access to Defog and U-turn also prolongs Mega Lopunny's longevity and lets it switch in unscathed. Special attackers like Hisuian Zoroark and Porygon-Z are able to break past physical walls Mega Lopunny can't, like Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Slowbro. Hisuian Zoroark also prevents Fighting-types from spamming their STAB moves aimed at Mega Lopunny.
