AcidPress (Dragon).description: Hisuian Goodra is a potent defensive backbone for Dragon teams, as thanks to its great typing and defensive stats, it acts as both a solid check to opposing Dragon-, Fairy-, and Ice-types and a special wall to foes such as Kyurem, Tapu Lele, and Mega Latias. Its IronPress combination also lets it act as a win condition. Protect raises Hisuian Goodra's longevity by letting it heal further with Leftovers and scout for super effective coverage from foes, but Rest can be used instead for further longevity at the cost of even more passivity; this can be mitigated with Chesto Berry, however. Shell Armor prevents foes from breaking past Hisuian Goodra's Defense boosts with a critical hit, but Sap Sipper provides an immunity to Leech Seed from foes such as Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Venusaur. As Hisuian Goodra can struggle with Fighting- and Ground-types such as Great Tusk, Mega Swampert, and Mega Lopunny, Mega Altaria and Latias make for good partners to check them, making a defensive core with Hisuian Goodra. This Hisuian Goodra set can struggle with Ghost-types such as Gholdengo, Ceruledge, and Mega Sableye, so partners such as Kommo-o, Garchomp, and Roaring Moon mitigate Hisuian Goodra's passivity against them. Roaring Moon in particular can also act as an offensive check to Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Mega Diancie, which can otherwise overwhelm Hisuian Goodra.

Screen Setter (Fairy).description: Klefki is the ideal dual screens setter on Fairy due to its Steel typing, which negates Poison-type attacks from Nihilego and Alolan Muk and ability to fend off threats like Mega Scizor with Foul Play. Klefki is a better option than Grimmsnarl due to its typing and ability to set up Spikes, which, like its screens, go up quickly with Prankster. This support allows for Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Azumarill from setting up and sweeping, teams. Foul Play prevents Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Mimikyu to set up and sweep while Thunder Wave cripples foes and allows Mega Diancie to outspeed threats such as +1 Mega Charizard X and Nihilego, which will normally beat Klefki one on one. Setting up Spikes creates solid chip damage on Alolan Muk and Gholdengo, allowing for late-game sweeping from its teammates Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Mega Diancie punishes opponents trying to set up entry hazards against Klefki and beats Fire-types such as Heatran and Mega Charizard Y. Tapu Bulu helps Klefki with Grassy Terrain, which halves the damage it takes from Earthquake, making Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Mamoswine not hit as hard.

Mixed Wallbreaker (Rock).description: Mega Diancie is the ideal Mega Evolution for Rock teams due to its ability to check Dragon-types like Kommo-o, punish passive Pokemon and entry hazard setters such as Toxapex and Klefki with Magic Bounce, and be a mixed wallbreaker that threatens Great Tusk and Galarian Slowking. Diamond Storm does considerable damage to special walls like Blissey and Alolan Muk and can also provide a Defense boost. Psychic heavily damages Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Nidoking, which eases the matchup against Poison teams. Earth Power deals heavy damage to Steel-type Pokemon like Heatran and Iron Treads and is paired nicely with Mystical Fire to damage Skarmory and Corviknight. On a hyper offensive team, Mega Diancie runs four attacks for coverage. With Shuckle's Sticky Web up, its good Speed tier becomes more devastating and outspeeds Pokemon like Mega Gallade and Zeraora. Mega Diancie also pairs well with Omastar and Terrakion, as Omastar takes care of the Ground matchup with a well-timed Shell Smash, while Terrakion's access to Earthquake and Close Combat takes care of most Steel-types. On bulky offense, Mega Diancie prefers to run Spikes, as the chip damage sets up a potential late-game cleanup from more offensive Pokemon on the team like Terrakion and Nihilego. Garganacl pairs well with Spikes, as Salt Cure forces a lot of Pokemon to switch out and take additional chip damage.

Mixed Wallbreaker (Fairy).description: Mega Diancie is a valuable asset to Fairy teams, featuring Magic Bounce to deflect entry hazards and status, wide coverage, and strong offensive capabilities with its high Speed. Diamond Storm often increases Mega Diancie's bulk and threatens foes like Enamorus and Mega Charizard Y. Moonblast handles threats like Mega Sableye and Latias. Earth Power can be used to counter Steel teams, OHKOing Heatran, Excadrill, and Magnezone, while dealing heavy damage to the likes of Skeledirge and Garganacl. Mystical Fire targets Steel-types that don't mind Earth Power, such as Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Scizor under Psychic Terrain. Alternatively, Mega Diancie can run Nature Power and use the various terrains set by its teammates to expand its wallbreaking abilities. Stealth Rock can be used to allow Mega Diancie to set its own hazard, but four attacks are recommended given Mega Diancie's wide coverage. Klefki provides Spikes and dual screens support which allows Mega Diancie to OHKO threats like Gholdengo, and it can also carry Thunder Wave to let Mega Diancie outspeed and take out threats like Mega Gallade and Mega Aerodactyl. Tapu Koko takes on Water-types and aids in the Steel matchup by forcing out Corviknight and Celesteela. Tapu Bulu counters Ground- and Water-types like Great Tusk and Urshifu-R, while Tapu Lele takes on Poison-types and prevents priority moves from Azumarill and Mega Scizor. Iron Valiant is a great partner for the Steel matchup, but it also benefits from Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain to outspeed and take out faster threats such as Zeraora and Greninja. All of these teammates appreciate Mega Diancie's ability to bounce hazards back to the opponent, as Fairy teams do not possess entry hazard removal.

Physically Defensive (Water).description: Toxapex is an incredible asset to Water teams due to its great defensive profile and wide range of utility options. Scald burns physical attackers such as Dragonite and Mega Lopunny, as well as Garchomp and Mega Gallade attempting to switch in. Poison Jab threatens Fairy- and Grass-types like Tapu Bulu, Iron Valiant, and Rillaboom. Toxic Spikes enhances offensive teammates such as Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Greninja, while Toxic lessens Toxapex's passivity, putting Gastrodon, Tornadus-T, and Mega Altaria on a timer. Haze allows Toxapex to shut down setup sweepers like Mega Scizor, Mimikyu, and Mega Altaria. Knock Off bothers item-reliant walls such as Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Celesteela. Black Sludge allows Toxapex to outlast tankier foes with the help of chip damage from Toxic Spikes and Toxic, while Heavy-Duty Boots enables it as a pivot, letting it sponge attacks without worrying about entry hazards. Teammates appreciate Toxapex absorbing Toxic Spikes and fighting off Grass-types like Meowscarada and Breloom. Toxapex appreciates Slowking and Rotom-W taking Psychic- and Ground-type moves, respectively. Mega Swampert switches into Electric-types like Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Magnezone and threatens Poison-types like opposing Toxapex, Clodsire, and Nidoking. Gastrodon forms a great defensive core with Toxapex, taking on the aforementioned Electric-types and providing entry hazards to further chip down pivots such as Meowscarada, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Moth. Greninja checks Ground-types like Clodsire, Garchomp, and Landorus and aids in the Flying matchup. Urshifu-R checks Pokemon like Kyurem and Hydreigon, which take advantage of Toxapex. Pelipper provides a Ground immunity against Landorus-T, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk and synergizes well with Toxapex against Grass teams.

Z-Haze (Poison).description: Toxapex is a main-stay on Poison teams due to its defensive typing, impeccable ability, ridiculous bulk, and utility moves like Toxic, Knock Off, and Haze. Scald allows Toxapex to spread burns on physical attackers such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Mega Scizor. Toxic puts threats like Rotom-W, Baxcalibur, and Urshifu-R on a timer and spreads chip damage on offensive teams like Dragon, Psychic, and Fire. Knock Off is another great option to bother Pokemon like Galarian Corsola and Celesteela. Haze, paired with Icium Z, shuts down setup sweepers like Z-Happy Hour Jirachi and Clangorous Soulblaze Kommo-o, immediately regaining its health to continue walling them. Toxic Spikes are an option instead of Toxic or Knock Off; however, Toxapex has other teammates capable of setting them up and it increases Toxapex's passivity. The given EV spread avoids an OHKO from +1 SpA Jirachi's Psychic, allowing Toxapex to activate its Z-Crystal. Mega Venusaur and Crobat are excellent teammates due to their Ground-type neutrality and immunity, respectively, checking Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Mamoswine, while the former also threatens Ferrothorn with Hidden Power Fire. Due to Toxapex's Psychic-type weakness, Alolan Muk and Galarian Slowking are notable teammates, checking Tapu Lele, Deoxys-S, and Latias; Galarian Slowking, in particular, forms a very strong Regenerator core with Toxapex. Clodsire and Nidoking patch up Toxapex's Electric-type weakness, and Nidoking specifically threatens Steel teams with its wide array of coverage. Galarian Weezing provides another Ground-type immunity and removes entry hazards with Defog as well as serving as a concrete answer to Baxcalibur. Sneasler appreciates Toxapex's ability to chip down foes, offering more opportunities for setup. Iron Moth threatens Steel-types like Celesteela, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo, which are otherwise difficult to break for Poison teams.

Sticky Web (Bug).description: Araquanid is the best defensive Sticky Web setter and a staple on Bug teams, as its ability Water Bubble combined with its high Special Defense gives it valuable defensive utility against Fire-types and special attackers. Liquidation threatens Fire- and Ground-types as well as physically frail Pokemon that don't resist Water like Iron Valiant, Enamorus, and Sneasler. Toxic punishes bulky switch-ins like Mantine, Rotom-W, Porygon2, and Volcanion. Magic Coat counters entry hazards and status spread from Pokemon like Shuckle, Celesteela, and Klefki that will attempt to exploit Araquanid's passivity. Leech Life is a niche option that gives Araquanid minor recovery and threatens Pokemon like Ogerpon-W, Hydreigon, Latios, and Latias. Mirror Coat is an option for Water-resistant foes and omniboost sweepers like Pelipper, Kommo-o, and Hisuian Zoroark, as Araquanid can comfortably take an attack and OHKO them in return. The given EV spread maximizes Araquanid's bulk while also outspeeding base 50 Speed Pokemon with no investment like Ursaluna, Ting-Lu, Hippowdon, and Alolan Muk, which are all threatened by Liquidation. Araquanid synergizes best with teammates that utilize the speed control Sticky Web provides and appreciate the elimination of Pokemon it counters. Volcarona greatly benefits from the removal of Fire-types like Heatran and Victini, making the opening for a sweep easier. With the Sticky Web speed decrease, Volcarona is able to outspeed its checks after only one Quiver Dance and deals with the Grass and Electric types Araquanid is countered by. Choice Scarf Kleavor is a great Stealth Rock setter that takes out Hisuian Arcanine, provides momentum with U-turn, and benefits from Sticky Web. Strong physical attackers like Heracross, Scizor, and Mega Pinsir break walls that Araquanid can't touch like Toxapex, Tapu Fini, and Ferrothorn; they also excel with Sticky Web support, letting them set up and outspeed their checks like Kyurem, Ceruledge, and Tapu Lele.

Swords Dance (Ghost).description: Mimikyu is an outstanding asset to Ghost teams, boasting both a valuable part-Fairy typing and a unique ability that complements revenge killing and late-game cleaning. Play Rough hits threatening Dark- and Dragon-types like Galarian Moltres, Mandibuzz, and Kommo-o. Shadow Claw notably allows Mimikyu to threaten Psychic teams even under Psychic Terrain, while Drain Punch deals more damage to Steel-types such as Iron Treads, Magnezone, and Excadrill and can mitigate Life Orb recoil. Shadow Sneak enables Mimikyu to revenge kill weakened foes and pick off faster threats like Blacephalon, Gengar, and Victini. Disguise almost always allows Mimikyu to set up a Swords Dance or revenge kill faster foes that Shadow Sneak cannot deal enough damage to. Mega Sableye is heavily appreciated due to its ability Magic Bounce, which adds to Mimikyu's longevity by bouncing back entry hazards and status moves aimed at it. Wallbreakers like Gholdengo wear down bulkier teams by checking walls such as Corviknight, Mega Venusaur, and Toxapex, which lets Mimikyu have an easier time cleaning up late-game. Blacephalon and Skeledirge threaten the Steel-types Mimikyu struggles against, like Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor. They can also cripple troublesome walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon with Trick and Will-O-Wisp, respectively. Hisuian Zoroark is deeply valued for its Ghost-type immunity, as it can catch Gholdengo and Gengar off guard.

Setup Sweeper (Fighting).description: An incredible asset for Fighting teams, Kommo-o is often the best wincon on the type thanks to Clangorous Soulblaze, which helps it overcome otherwise difficult matchups such as Dragon, Flying, and Water. Flamethrower takes care of Steel-type Pokemon neutral to Drain Punch like Mega Scizor and Corviknight. Taunt allows Kommo-o to block status moves from defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Swampert, and Gliscor, preventing them from resetting its boosts with Haze or statusing it with Toxic. Alternatively, Clangorous Soul powers up Kommo-o without using its Z-Move, letting its Clangorous Soulblaze outright OHKO Toxapex and Hippowdon, at the cost of longevity. Bulletproof is Kommo-o's preferred ability to better handle Gholdengo or Aegislash in the Steel matchup. Unboosted Kommo-o's average Speed tier leaves it outsped by threats to Fighting teams like Tornadus-T and Tapu Lele, so Choice Scarf users like Galarian Zapdos and Terrakion are great partners to assist it against them. Iron Valiant's Fairy typing and wide coverage movepool lets it deal with opposing Dragon-types, and it forms a wallbreaking core with Kommo-o by pressuring the likes of Mega Sableye and Ting-Lu. Cobalion and Great Tusk provide Stealth Rock, which maximizes Kommo-o's opportunities to wallbreak after using Clangorous Soulblaze. Great Tusk can also remove entry hazards for Kommo-o with Rapid Spin, and Cobalion has the added bonus of checking Fairy-types like Mega Diancie. Mega Gallade can pressure Poison-, Ground-, and Flying-types like Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T for Kommo-o. It can also outspeed and revenge kill offensive threats to it like Kyurem and Garchomp.

Mixed Omni-Boost Sweeper (Dragon).description: Kommo-o is an exceptional setup sweeper due to its great mixed offensive stats, respectable defenses, and exclusive access to Clangorous Soulblaze; this makes it an amazing tool to clean up Steel, Dark, and Dragon teams late-game. Drain Punch threatens Steel- and Normal-types like Heatran, Blissey, and Porygon-2 as well as increasing Kommo-o's longevity, making it harder for revenge killers to shut it down after using its Z-Move. Additionally, Drain Punch is Kommo-o's best move to hit Ditto, as it copies its ability Soundproof. Flamethrower targets Fighting-resistant or -immune Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Celesteela, and Aegislash. Taunt is preferred to shut down phazers like Haze Toxapex and Hippowdon and bulky walls like Porygon2 and Clodsire, which can inconvenience Kommo-o with Toxic. Meanwhile, Clangorous Soul allows for more boosts and breaking power, notably enabling Clangorous Soulblaze to OHKO the aforementioned Hippowdon and Toxapex. Furthermore, Clangorous Soulblaze allows Kommo-o to set up on Fairy-types and Soundproof Pokemon like Alolan Ninetales, Trace Porygon2, and opposing Kommo-o. Soundproof prevents revenge killing attempts from Ditto or opposing Kommo-o, and a Naive nature permits Kommo-o to outpace Mega Aerodactyl, Mega Lopunny, and Zeraora after obtaining the omni-boost. Mega Altaria is a wonderful teammate, as it helps weaken and clean up opposing Dragon teams; In return, it appreciates Kommo-o dealing with the aforementioned Steel-types. Kyurem aids in matchups against Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Mantine, and Dragonite, as well as Fairy-types such as Azumarill, Tapu Fini, and Mega Altaria. Choice Scarf Latias and Roaring Moon provide speed control; the former offers healing and setup opportunities with Healing Wish, while the latter checks Psychic-types like Deoxys-S, Victini, and Latias. Garchomp offers entry hazards support to pressure and chip down Kommo-o's switch-ins and aids in the Steel matchup with Earthquake. Hisuian Goodra is a huge help in the Fairy matchup, taking on Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Mega Diancie. Mega Latios threatens Flying-type threats with its BoltBeam coverage; in addition, when paired with Garchomp, it puts a lot of pressure on Poison teams, which Kommo-o tends to struggle against. Cyclizar provides entry hazard control with Rapid Spin and extra protection for Kommo-o with Shed Tail, encouraging the use of Clangorous Soul over Taunt. Baxcalibur is excellent in the Dark and Flying matchups, dispatching threats like Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Enamorus with its Swords Dance or Dragon Dance set, and it also ravages Poison teams with Galarian Slowking, which Kommo-o might not be able to handle. In return, Kommo-o removes the aforementioned Steel- and Normal-types that can easily wall Baxcalibur or use it to reverse sweep, specifically Ditto.

Choice Specs (Electric).description: Tapu Koko is a dominant force within Electric teams due to its exceptional ability, Electric Surge, which its teammates benefit from. Tapu Koko further boasts a good Speed tier and valuable Fairy-typing, rendering it a menacing threat in its own right. Dazzling Gleam levels the playing field in the Dragon matchup, eliminating foes such as Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Baxcalibur, and Mega Altaria, but it's also useful against threats like Mega Lopunny and non-Choice Scarf Great Tusk. Grass Knot provides much needed coverage against troublesome Ground-types, most notably taking care of Swampert, Quagsire, Gastrodon, and Mamoswine. Volt Switch pairs wells with Tapu Koko's speed, allowing it to escape unfavorable matchups and bring in teammates like Zapdos against the likes of Mega Venusaur or Mega Scizor. Hidden Power Ice can be used to deal with Ground-types that aren't threatened by Grass Knot such as Garchomp and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Thunderbolt can be run to increase Tapu Koko's damage output, giving it a chance to OHKO foes like Mega Diancie. Rotom-W and Zapdos are excellent partners to Tapu Koko, as they provide a necessary Ground immunity as well as Defog support, which allows Tapu Koko to pivot more freely. Rotom-W further helps by handling Ground-types and spreading burns to strong physical attackers like Mega Garchomp, Iron Valiant, Dragonite, and Mega Swampert in rain, while Zapdos walls and makes use of Heat Wave to deal with Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Iron Treads and Hurricane to counter pesky Grass- and Fighting-types like Tapu Bulu, Mega Venusaur, and Mega Gallade. Alolan Raichu's Surge Surfer fully capitalizes on Electric Terrain, turning it into a serious revenge killer, capable of outspeeding threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Mega Aerodactyl, and Iron Valiant under Quark Drive. Iron Hands and Zeraora are prominent partners for Tapu Koko complementing it as Physical breakers, both being able to take care of foes such as defensive Zapdos, Ursaluna and Alolan Muk which hinder Tapu Koko and other Special attackers. Iron Hands has more bulk and longevity, but Zeraora brings near unmatched Speed to the table. Both of them also appreciate Tapu Koko's ability to remove Mega Sableye and Skeledirge and luring in and critically damaging Landorus-Therian with Hidden Power Ice. Regieleki brings raw Electric-type power in the form of a boosted Rising Voltage, which is capable of sweeping teams that don't have an answer to it, and it also provides hazard removal thanks to Rapid Spin. Magnezone provides an immunity to Poison, which Tapu Koko appreciates, and more importantly traps and removes threats such as Mega Scizor and Excadrill with Hidden Power Fire.

Fast Pivot (Fairy).description: Boasting a great Speed tier and solid coverage, Tapu Koko not only provides Electric Terrain to enable Iron Valiant, but also provides a means to deal with Flying's defensive core for Fairy teams thanks to its access to Thunderbolt and Hidden Power Ice. Thunderbolt is Tapu Koko's most spammable attack, which it uses to eliminate roadblocks such as Corviknight, Celesteela, and Toxapex, but Discharge can be used to spread paralysis against faster foes. Hidden Power Ice threatens Ground-types such as Landorus and Gliscor. U-turn is its preferred pivot option, as Tapu Koko lures in Ground-types like Ursaluna and Great Tusk that block Volt Switch, which Iron Valiant and Tapu Bulu can then handle. That said, it can also run Toxic to wear down walls like Zapdos and Hippowdon, or Taunt to shut down entry hazard and dual screens setters like Klefki, Jirachi, and Galvantula or setup sweepers like Volcarona. Roost extends Tapu Koko's longevity and thus its opportunities to pivot. Heavy-Duty Boots pairs well with Tapu Koko's role as a pivot, but Expert Belt increases its chances to OHKO Landorus with Hidden Power Ice and Toxapex with Thunderbolt. Tapu Koko's partner in crime on Fairy teams is Iron Valiant, which appreciates being pivoted into for Quark Drive to be activated and returns the favor by dealing with Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, and even some Poison-types like Alolan Muk and Mega Venusaur when using a Fightinium Z and Psychium Z, respectively. Mega Diancie provides some form of hazard control with Magic Bounce, which Tapu Koko especially appreciates if it's not running Heavy-Duty Boots, and it can handle troublesome Flying- and Fire-types such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Klefki is another great partner, as it sets up screens, allowing Tapu Koko to pivot more freely, and provides a valuable immunity to Poison. Tapu Lele and Tapu Bulu serve as powerful wallbreakers that can weaken the opposing team to allow Tapu Koko to clean late-game. Tapu Lele handles foes such as Clodsire, Mega Venusaur, Nidoking, and even Mega Scizor when running Hidden Power Fire, while Tapu Bulu powers through Ground-types that don't fear Tapu Koko's Hidden Power Ice, such as Mega Swampert, Gastrodon, and Hippowdon. Belly Drum Azumarill also helps in the Ground matchup,and it can utilize its priority move Aqua Jet to eliminate faster threats such as Gengar and Nihilego.

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is one of Psychic teams' greatest revenge killers. Its decent Speed tier and astounding offensive prowess combined with its great typing makes it extremely threatening because with access to STAB Moonblast, it is Psychic's best check to most Dark-type threats. Tapu Lele's presence also sets up Psychic Terrain, shielding itself and its team from dangerous priority such as Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak and Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch. Focus Blast lets it easily take care of the pesky Steel-types that resist its STAB attacks such as Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Iron Treads. Future Sight lets Tapu Lele set up an attack for later and then switch out to a teammate such as Victini or Mega Gallade to help it set up or get a KO. Shadow Ball lets it beat Gholdengo and clean up against Psychic and Ghost teams, while Thunderbolt gives it general coverage versus foes like Mantine and Celesteela. Tapu Lele is often not able to beat specially defensive walls such as Alolan Muk and Blissey; hence, it appreciates partnering up with Mega Gallade to eliminate them. Mega Alakazam is a good partner, as it helps in the Electric and Water matchups courtesy of Trace copying Surge Surfer and Swift Swim, respectively, and it appreciates Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain boosting its Expanding Force. Slowbro sponges hits from faster Choice Scarf users such as Terrakion and Galarian Zapdos, and can also pivot Tapu Lele in with Teleport to wreak havoc. Victini and Armarouge can eliminate Steel-types, especially Aegislash and Gholdengo, easing the burden for Tapu Lele. Jirachi can slow teams down with Thunder Wave and pivot Tapu Lele into physical walls such as Mandibuzz and Slowbro with U-turn.

Choice Scarf (Fairy).description: Tapu Lele's Psychic Surge ability and complementary STAB types along with excellent coverage moves allow it to shine as a cleaner on Fairy teams. Psychic is its preferred Psychic-type STAB move, which it uses to take out Poison-types such as Toxapex, Nidoking, and Mega Venusaur, though it can also run Psyshock to hit Clodsire harder. Moonblast deals with Dark- and Dragon-types like Mega Sableye, Galarian Moltres, Kommo-o, and Latias. Focus Blast checks threats such as Heatran and Iron Treads. Hidden Power Fire OHKOes most Mega Scizor sets, while Thunderbolt threatens a wider selection of Water- and Flying-types like Celesteela, Mantine, and Mega Charizard Y. Shadow Ball could also be used to provide coverage against Aegislash and Gholdengo. Thanks to Psychic Surge, Tapu Lele shuts down priority moves from revenge killers and setup sweepers such as Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, Azumarill's Aqua Jet, and Dragonite's Extreme Speed, allowing it to KO them with Hidden Power Fire, Thunderbolt, and Moonblast, respectively. Choice Scarf allows Tapu Lele to outspeed threats such as Zeraora, Choice Scarf Excadrill, Tapu Koko, and Mega Lopunny. Tapu Lele pairs well with wallbreakers like Tapu Bulu and Azumarill that can weaken or eliminate its checks, with the former taking care of Meowscarada, Rotom-W, and Gastrodon, while the latter handles Volcarona, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Landorus. Tapu Koko helps in the Water- and Flying-type matchups by dealing with Landorus and Corviknight and offers a great Speed tier and coverage. Iron Valiant answers Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra and uses All-Out Pummeling to eliminate Dark-types like Alolan Muk, one of the best counters to Tapu Lele, and Ting-Lu, which could tank a few hits from Tapu Lele and threaten it with Poison Jab or Heavy Slam. The duo of Tapu Koko and Iron Valiant further assists Tapu Lele's late-game cleaning, as Tapu Koko activates Iron Valiant's Quark Drive, allowing it to outspeed common Choice Scarf users that are faster than Tapu Lele like Terrakion, Blacephalon, and Nihilego. Klefki's utility moves, such as Spikes, Thunder Wave, and dual screens, make it an excellent supporting partner. Thanks to Foul Play, Klefki is also able to answer bulky Swords Dance Mega Scizor, which could otherwise tank a Hidden Power Fire from Tapu Lele and KO it. Mega Diancie contributes to keeping Tapu Lele healthy by threatening hazard setters with Magic Bounce as well as Fire-types like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona, which can be troublesome to deal with for Tapu Lele. Mimikyu is a great partner in the Ghost matchup, being able to threaten fast foes such as Blacephalon. Ribombee's Sticky Web allows Tapu Lele to outrun faster Choice Scarf users such as Sneasler, Iron Valiant, and Gengar.

Swords Dance (Fairy).description: Tapu Bulu is a fearsome wallbreaker, boasting synergistic coverage moves that help Fairy teams in a variety of matchups like Water, Poison, and Ground. Close Combat targets Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn. Should Fightinium Z be used, All-Out Pummeling heavily damages the likes of Celesteela and Corviknight after a Swords Dance boost. High Horsepower heavily damages Aegislash and Gholdengo and lets Tapu Bulu be a massive asset against Steel and Water teams by hitting Toxapex for heavy damage. Substitute allows Tapu Bulu to set up on passive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Swampert, and Mega Sableye, while Zen Headbutt is its best move against Mega Venusaur and Crobat. Klefki is a great teammate, as it sets up Spikes to ease Tapu Bulu's wallbreaking as well as Reflect and Light Screen to provide more setup opportunities. Mega Diancie threatens Flying- and Fire-types like Zapdos, Dragonite, and Volcarona for Tapu Bulu. In return, Tapu Bulu checks Gastrodon, Heatran, and Clodsire, letting Mega Diancie have more leeway on its moveset. Similarly, Tapu Koko is heavily appreciated, as it also deals with Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y and relieves Tapu Bulu of having to use Fightinium Z, or waste its Z-Move, to threaten Corviknight and Celesteela.

Physically Defensive (Flying).description: With an amazing defensive typing and defensive stats, Celesteela is a great wall on Flying teams, taking hits from the likes of Iron Boulder, Weavile, and Mega Diancie. Celesteela takes advantage of its weight to threaten Rock-, Ice-, and Fairy-types such as Ogerpon-C, Nihilego, Weavile, and Tapu Lele with Heavy Slam. Leech Seed provides additional recovery for Celesteela on top of Leftovers and wears down foes that lack recovery like Barraskewda and Latias. Protect allows Celesteela to both guarantee recovery from Leftovers and scout moves from Choice-locked foes like Blacephalon and Zeraora. Toxic spreads status to foes on top of Leech Seed, wearing down walls such as Mantine in the process. Air Slash threatens Fighting- and Grass-types such as Mega Gallade, Keldeo, and Hisuian Lilligant. Flamethrower threatens the aforementioned Grass-types as well as Steel-types like Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight. 248 HP and 48 Special Defense EVs allow Celesteela to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Specs Greninja's Ice Beam and Choice Scarf Iron Valiant's Thunderbolt, while the remaining EVs are invested into Defense so it can take hits from Mega Lopunny and Mega Gallade. Mantine forms a defensive pairing with Celesteela, as its Water typing and its ability Water Absorb makes it great against Fire- and Water-types like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Urshifu-R. Gliscor's Ground typing and STAB Earthquake make it an important asset in the Electric matchup, and it helps Celesteela make progress against opposing teams with entry hazards, spread status with Toxic, and remove items with Knock Off. Landorus threatens Fire- and Electric-types such as Heatran, Ceruledge, and Raging Bolt. In return, it appreciates Celesteela checking Ice- and Fairy-types like Weavile, Iron Valiant, and Alolan Ninetales. Galarian Moltres and Dragonite appreciate Celesteela removing threats such as Enamorus and Ogerpon-C so they can begin sweeping. In return, Galarian Moltres takes out Ghost-types like Ceruledge and Blacephalon for Celesteela, while Dragonite handles Steel- and Electric-types such as Heatran, Magnezone, and Raging Bolt.

Mixed Wall (Steel).description: Boasting incredible defensive stats, an assortment of utility options, and a wonderful typing, Celesteela cements itself as a staple on Steel teams, easing the Ground and Fairy matchups as well as forcing progress against opposing Steel teams due to Flamethrower and Leech Seed. Flamethrower targets Steel-types that resist Heavy Slam such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Mega Scizor, while Air Slash threatens Fighting-types like Mega Gallade, Great Tusk, and Kommo-o. Alternatively, Toxic may be used to put bulkier Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Gastrodon on a timer, however, without Flamethrower, Celesteela is extremely passive in front of the aforementioned Steel-types, as well as Ferrothorn and Gholdengo which are immune to Leech Seed. Giga Drain is another option to improve the Water and Ground matchups, hitting Gastrodon, Mega Swampert, and Slowbro as well as improving longevity, however, it's a lot more matchup reliant than the other listed options. Protect in conjunction with Leech Seed is Celesteela's main method of forcing progress, spreading chip damage while also massively boosting its longevity. The given EV spread allows Celesteela to survive two consecutive uses of Close Combat from the likes of Mega Lopunny in addition to Choice Scarf Buzzwole and Terrakion. Heatran is by far Celesteela's most advantageous teammate due to its immunity to Fire-type moves letting it take on threats such as Volcarona and Blacephalon. In return, Celesteela walls Ground-types like Clodsire and Hippowdon. Ferrothorn is an essential teammate due to its ability to check Water-types such as Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W as well as provide utility in the form of entry hazards and additional Leech Seed support, wearing down teams greatly. Furthermore, Ferrothorn is a great answer to Electric-type Pokemon like Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Alolan Raichu. Ghost-type teammates such as Aegislash and Gholdengo alleviate the Fighting matchup, lessening the amount of pressure put onto Celesteela as a primary switch-in and also removing threats like Skeledirge, Slowbro, and Toxapex. Choice Scarf Iron Treads and Excadrill provide an immunity against the aforementioned Electric-type Pokemon, while the former checks Landorus with Ice Spinner and the latter hinders Mega Sableye with Toxic. Furthermore, Excadrill and Iron Treads are Steel's best answers to Ogerpon-H. Mega Scizor is a great pivot into Knock Off and can take on Fighting-types due to its neutrality to them and access to Roost. Assault Vest Melmetal is a great blanket check to special attackers like Tapu Koko, Kyurem, and Gholdengo, while Hisuian Goodra is an excellent sponge for Water-type attacks, walling Volcanion, Choice Specs Pelipper, and Basculegion-F.

Choice Scarf (Fire).description: Choice Scarf Blacephalon is a great late-game cleaner and provides great speed control on Fire teams, outspeeding and removing various offensive threats like Tapu Lele and Nihilego. Psyshock targets Poison- and Fighting-types like Nihilego and Keldeo. Trick allows Blacephalon to shift its Choice Scarf to passive walls like Ting-Lu and Mantine, restricting their options. Hidden Power Ice targets Dragon- and Ground-types such as Garchomp and the Landorus formes. Ninetales and Torkoal set up sun for Blacephalon to make Flamethrower its strongest cleaning option, notably OHKOing Iron Valiant, Enamorus, and Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock. Additionally, Ninetales provides Healing Wish support, while Torkoal sets up Stealth Rock and removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin so Blacephalon can switch in more easily. Cinderace also provides entry hazard control with Court Change, with it potentially being able to steal foes' dual screens; and it handles Dark-, Normal-, and Psychic-types like Tyranitar, Blissey, and Iron Boulder with High Jump Kick and Sucker Punch, respectively. It also brings Blacephalon in with U-turn. In return, Cinderace appreciates Blacephalon dealing with Ghost-types, which can switch in on a predicted High Jump Kick. Early-game wallbreakers such as Choice Band Victini and Hisuian Arcanine remove walls for Blacephalon. Victini breezes through Water- and Flying-types such as Empoleon and Mantine, while Hisuian Arcanine revenge kills boosted sweepers such as Alolan Raichu and Volcarona with Extreme Speed. Thanks to Blacephalon's great Speed tier, which lets it take out threats like Garchomp, it can enable late-game sweepers such as Volcarona, Z-Celebrate Victini, and Mega Charizard X.

Choice Scarf (Ghost).description: Boasting an astonishing Special Attack stat, great Speed tier, and deadly STAB combination, Blacephalon is an esteemed revenge killer on Ghost teams, easily cleaning through weakened Steel, Fairy, and Flying teams due to Beast Boost. Fire Blast provides more power to OHKO foes like Tapu Koko and Great Tusk at the cost of lowered accuracy. Hidden Power Ice targets Ground- and Dragon-types that aren't threatened by Blacephalon's STAB combination such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Dragonite. Alternatively, Blacephalon may use Psyshock to break through Clodsire, Kommo-o, and Nihilego. Trick immobilizes switch-ins like Alolan Muk, Iron Hands, and Blissey but can also be used on the aforementioned targets of Psyshock. With a Choice Scarf, Blacephalon manages to outpace Weavile, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Tapu Koko, allowing it to revenge kill them. Mimikyu is a great wallbreaker, capable of weakening Dark, Fighting, and Dragon teams, setting Blacephalon up for success late-game. Mega Sableye prevents the setting of Stealth Rock, allowing Blacephalon to pivot freely. Gholdengo threatens Fairy-type Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Clefable and takes advantage of passive Blacephalon switch-ins like Toxapex and Blissey. Hisuian Zoroark's immunity to Ghost-type moves is heavily appreciated, and it lures in Dark-types such as Hydreigon, Mega Tyranitar, and Ting-Lu with Illusion, hitting them with Focus Blast. Furthermore, Hisuian Zoroark can bluff other Blacephalon switch-ins—such as Heatran and Toxapex—to eliminate them, easing Blacephalon's job later into the match. Froslass and Galarian Corsola offer entry hazards to wear down Blacephalon's switch-ins and spread status ailments to ease Blacephalon's sweeping.

Physical Wallbreaker.description: Choice Band Zeraora is a fearsome wallbreaker on Electric teams thanks to its incredible Speed stat and respectable Attack. Close Combat threatens foes like Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Hisuian Goodra that try to wall Zeraora or its teammates, while Knock Off scares off Ghost- and Psychic-types like Sinistcha, Galarian Slowking, and Jirachi. Play Rough hits Dragon- and Fighting-types like Mega Altaria, Hydreigon, and Mega Gallade for massive damage. Tapu Koko complements Zeraora by providing Electric Terrain to amp up Plasma Fists, notably allowing Zeraora to OHKO Mega Diancie with the power boost while hitting Dark-, Dragon-, and Ground-types like Mega Sableye, Mega Altaria, and the Landorus formes with its strong Dazzling Gleam and Hidden Power Ice. Tapu Koko appreciates Zeraora dispatching specially defensive walls like Chansey, Alolan Muk, and Hisuian Goodra with its strong Plasma Fists and Close Combat. Both Rotom-W and Zapdos are great teammates by virtue of their Ground immunity; Rotom-W can pivot Zeraora in on the aforementioned walls, wash away Ground-types with Hydro Pump, and remove entry hazards with Defog, while Zapdos greatly appreciates said walls being broken down and demolishes Grass-types like Mega Venusaur in return. Iron Hands provides a defensive sponge against Choice Scarf users such as Hisuian Arcanine, Kleavor, and Gholdengo and provides entry points thanks to its slow Volt Switch. After a Nasty Plot, Alolan Raichu can deal with troubling Poison- and Ground-types like Mega Venusaur, Water Absorb Clodsire, and Hippowdon thanks to its strong Z-Psyshock and Grass Knot, greatly aiding Zeraora's wallbreaking efforts.

Offensive Utility.description: Cinderace acts as role compression on Fire teams, being able to apply offensive pressure on foes like Azumarill and non-Choice Scarf Hydreigon with its coverage, remove entry hazards with Court Change, and revenge kill faster threats such as Iron Boulder and Ceruledge with Sucker Punch. Pyro Ball and Gunk Shot can be used over Sucker Punch, with the former handling Bug- and Steel-types like Scizor and Corviknight and the latter taking on Fairy-types like Clefable and non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant. High Jump Kick allows Cinderace to deal with Normal-, Rock-, and Dark-types such as Blissey, Mega Tyranitar, and Ting-Lu. Iron Head is a niche option that allows Cinderace to lure in and remove Mega Diancie in the Fairy matchup. With U-turn, Cinderace can pivot out of unfavorable matchups such as Toxapex and Great Tusk and bring in a teammate that can deal with them. Heatran and Iron Moth are such teammates, with the former handling Toxapex by trapping it with Magma Storm and removing it with Earth Power and the latter taking Great Tusk out with Energy Ball. When it forgoes Sucker Punch, Cinderace appreciates Choice Scarf Blacephalon taking on Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Ceruledge, which can switch into High Jump Kick, and in return, Cinderace takes on Dark-types for Blacephalon. Torkoal sets up sun to boost Pyro Ball when it's being run and places Stealth Rock to further aid Cinderace. Notably, sun-boosted Pyro Ball 2HKOes Mega Sableye. When Cinderace runs Sucker Punch, its ability to revenge kill faster and weakened threats like Iron Boulder enables setup sweepers such as Mega Charizard X, Volcarona, Z-Celebrate Victini, and Ceruledge to start their own sweep, and the latter two specifically appreciate Court Change support so they can find an opportunity to switch in.

Defensive Pivot (Flying).description: With crucial neutralities to Rock and Ice, as well as several other resistances that let it wall several metagame threats such as Mamoswine, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Boulder, Corviknight is a solid entry hazard remover and pivot that mitigates the weakness to Stealth Rock commonly found on Flying teams. Body Press minimizes its passivity, notably hitting foes such as Mega Lopunny, Weavile, and Ogerpon-C, but Iron Head can be used instead to hit Fairy-types like Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Alolan Ninetales. Pressure ensures that Corviknight doesn't run out of Defog PP as easily because it can switch into foes setting up Stealth Rock and lower their PP, such as Piloswine, Archaludon, and Ferrothorn, but Mirror Armor can be used instead to avoid a 2HKO from Mega Diancie's Mystical Fire. The first EV spread, even if Corviknight loses Leftovers, avoids a 2HKO from Mega Gallade's Close Combat, a 2HKO from Mega Lopunny's Close Combat after Stealth Rock, and an OHKO from Great Tusk's +1 All-Out Pummeling. However, the alternate EV spread still avoids a 2HKO from Mega Lopunny's Close Combat, and it avoids a 2HKO from Choice Specs Protean Greninja's Ice Beam with Leftovers recovery. Mantine is a solid partner for Corviknight, as it can switch into Fire-types such as Mega Charizard Y, Volcarona, and Heatran, and it also forms a defensive core by more consistently handling special attackers for it. Corviknight's role compression also allows Mantine to run Toxic over Defog, or if Mantine is desired as a Defogger instead, Corviknight can run Iron Head + Body Press. Gliscor and Landorus are also good allies to switch into Electric-types that force out Corviknight such as Zapdos, Raging Bolt, Zeraora, and Alolan Raichu, in turn also forming a pivoting core with Corviknight. Offensive Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y, Mega Aerodactyl, and Tornadus-T appreciate Corviknight's slow pivoting to safely be brought onto the field; in return, they act as offensive checks to foes that Corviknight can't threaten by itself such as Great Tusk, Mega Gallade, and Ogerpon-W.

Rain Sweeper (Water).description: Barraskewda functions as one of the best sweepers on rain Water teams, in part thanks to its high Speed tier, which is increased further under rain due to its ability Swift Swim, allowing it to outspeed the entire tier. Flip Turn allows Barraskewda to pivot out of Pokemon like Corviknight and Rotom-W, which are not OHKOed by rain-boosted Liquidation, while still dealing respectable damage and maintaining momentum to get in its teammates to deal with these Pokemon. Close Combat is the strongest coverage move that Barraskewda has access to and it most notably threatens Ferrothorn, which is able to take Liquidation from Barraskewda. Psychic Fangs in conjunction with an Adamant nature lets Barraskewda 2HKO Mega Venusaur and Toxapex, and its secondary effect of destroying dual screens, while situational, is useful in the Fairy matchup. Crunch is an alternative option to let Barraskewda target Psychic-types like Latios, Mega Latias, and Slowbro, which are able to switch into Liquidation. Poison Jab is also an option to target Fairy-types like Tapu Bulu and Azumarill, which resist Liquidation and Close Combat. A Jolly nature is preferred to outspeed Tapu Koko and Mega Lopunny, whereas an Adamant nature can also be run to achieve the aforementioned results with Psychic Fangs. Pelipper is a mandatory partner of Barraskewda, as it not only sets rain but also offers a slow U-turn as a form of pivoting, which lets Barraskewda get on the field safely, and its ability to threaten opposing Grass teams with Hurricane helps Barraskewda get past Pokemon like Mega Venusaur. Mega Swampert can form a potent Swift Swim offensive core with Barraskewda, wearing down each other's checks such as Ferrothorn and Porygon2. Swampert also works well with Barraskewda, offering hazard support in Stealth Rock to weaken opposing Pokemon so Barraskewda can secure KOs. It also provides slow pivoting with Flip Turn, and its Ground typing is a must to stave off opposing Electric-types like Regieleki, which are faster than Barraskewda outside of rain. Toxapex is also a strong defensive teammate for Barraskewda, being able to cripple Barraskewda's checks with Toxic and also handle setup sweepers like Mega Altaria and Mega Scizor with Haze. Greninja is able to break past physically defensive walls like opposing Toxapex, Mega Scizor, and Mega Venusaur, which are reliable answers to Barraskewda, while Greninja appreciates Barraskewda being able to handle specially defensive walls like Blissey and Ting-Lu.

Slush Rush (Ice).description:
A Naughty nature lets Arctozolt OHKO Physically Defensive Toxapex with Bolt Beak after Stealth Rock damage and should be in tandem with Freeze-Dry to fully threaten Water teams as it deals with Swampert. On the other hand, a Naive nature lets Arctozolt outspeed Zeraora and Choice Scarf Excadrill under Snow, making Stomping Tantrum a better choice if using the aforementioned nature.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Band (Water).description: Choice Band Urshifu-R is a strong wallbreaker on Water teams, taking on bulky foes like Ferrothorn, Archaludon, Kyurem, and Mandibuzz. Aqua Jet is a strong priority option to pick off faster albeit weakened sweepers and cleaners such as Ceruledge and Sneasler. Thunder Punch targets Water- and Flying-types like Toxapex, Pelipper, and Mantine, while Ice Spinner handles Dragon- and Ground-types such as Dragonite and Clodsire. However, Aqua Jet is preferred, since it stops opposing sweepers and cleaners in their tracks to enable its teammates to sweep or clean late-game. U-turn allows Urshifu-R to pivot out of unfavorable matchups, such as against Mantine and Dragonite, and bring a teammate in to deal with them. Pelipper is not only neutral to Grass, but it also sets up rain to boost Urshifu-R's Water-type STAB attacks, turning it into a potential late-game cleaner with rain-boosted Aqua Jet. It notably has a good chance of OHKOing Alolan Raichu with Aqua Jet under rain, and rain further makes Surging Strikes harder to switch into. Additionally, Pelipper removes entry hazards with Defog and pivots it in safely with U-turn. Swift Swim users such as Mega Swampert and Barraskewda thus make for great teammates as well, as they appreciate Urshifu-R's wallbreaking so they can clean late-game. Mega Swampert also provides an Electric immunity to deal with the likes of Tapu Koko, Regieleki, and Zeraora. Toxapex and Empoleon are great defensive partners due to their part-Poison and part-Steel typings, respectively, that allow them to take on Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie and Alolan Ninetales, which Urshifu-R dislikes. Additionally, they can stack entry hazards with Toxic Spikes and Stealth Rock, respectively, to aid Urshifu-R in wallbreaking, and Toxapex also removes boosts from setup sweepers with Haze. Greninja forms a strong wallbreaking duo with Urshifu-R, with it taking on the likes of Sinistcha, the Ogerpon formes, and non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant for Urshifu-R, while it appreciates the removal of Ferrothorn and Empoleon in return. Ogerpon-W eases the Ground matchup thanks to its resistance, handling the Landorus formes and Garchomp in the process.

Choice Scarf (Bug).description: Choice Scarf Kleavor is one of the best answers to Flying- and Fire-types, like Tornadus-T, Mega Charizard-Y, and Skeledirge, for Bug teams, thanks to its Sharpness-boosted Stone Axe, which has the added utility of automatically setting Stealth Rock. Close Combat synergizes well with Kleavor's STAB moves, crushing Steel-types like Iron Treads. U-turn allows Kleavor to pivot out of Great Tusk and Skarmory to bring in teammates like Araquanid or Volcarona. Night Slash banishes Ghost-types like Gholdengo, Knock Off softens walls like Corviknight and Porygon2 for its teammates, and X-Scissor takes down Slowbro to make way for Mega Pinsir. Araquanid and Galvantula are excellent teammates, as these set up Sticky Web to patch up Kleavor's unassuming speed, even when using a Choice Scarf, allowing it to outspeed Choice Scarf Blacephalon. Additionally, they also help in dealing with pesky Fire- and Flying-types like Volcarona and Landorus, respectively. Physical setup sweepers benefit from Kleavor's ability to set hazards offensively, Knock Off items from walls, and deal with Skeledirge and Slowbro, which often wall Mega Pinsir, Scizor, and Mega Scizor. In return, they deal with Fighting- and Fairy-types like Great Tusk and Mega Diancie. Quiver Dance Volcarona appreciates Skeledirge removed, as this lets it clean up Ghost teams at +1; it can also be brought in against passive walls like Slowbro and Skarmory. Forretress provides Rapid Spin and loves Kleavor's ability to set Stealth Rock, as this allows it to run other hazards like Toxic Spikes or Volt Switch to better support the team. Lokix provides great offensive support with its access to priority in First Impression and Sucker Punch to finish off teams weakened by Kleavor through entry hazards and repeated Knock Offs. It is also a secondary check to Skeledirge, which Bug teams appreciate.

Swords Dance (Normal).description:
A Jolly nature is more desireable as most defensive walls only invest enough Speed for Adamant Azumarill, which speedties with Ursaluna.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Fighting).description: Choice Scarf Sneasler is an extremely fast revenge killer that decimates Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Quark Drive-boosted Iron Valiant, and Adamant Sand Rush Excadrill for Fighting teams. Close Combat and Dire Claw have near-perfect synergy, aside from Dire Claw's ability to punish passive answers—like Toxapex and Slowbro—that swap into its STAB moves. U-turn pivots Sneasler out of switch-ins such as Skeledirge, Aegislash, and Gliscor, bringing in Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Mega Gallade. Switcheroo further punishes walls like Corviknight if the extra speed is unneeded. Alternatively, Rock Slide lets it revenge kill Quiver Dance Volcarona, freeing up a moveslot on Iron Hands, while Toxic Spikes greatly pressure Fairy teams wary of Dire Claw. Night Slash can also be the final move for Sneasler, as it notably hits Gholdengo and Aegislash, but pivoting out of these threats is usually the better option. Choice Scarf Sneasler is a late-game cleaner, so wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as the aforementioned Kommo-o and Mega Gallade are appreciated, as these deal with Corviknight, Gliscor, and Toxapex. Kommo-o also benefits from Sneasler dealing with Fairy-types, as this allows Kommo-o to use Clangorous Soulblaze. Choice Specs Iron Valiant loves being pivoted in safely against physical walls like Skeledirge and Mega Sableye, which wall Sneasler. Assault Vest Iron Hands is a soft check against Gholdengo and Volcarona and can pivot Sneasler in against walls, which it can inconvenience. Hisuian Lilligant and Breloom deal with Gastrodon and Quagsire and also ease the Water and Ground matchups. As with the other setup sweepers, these also love the setup opportunities Sneasler opens up by being able to punish walls with Dire Claw's additional effects or with Switcheroo. Entry hazard support from Cobalion and Great Tusk is also appreciated, and these provide a secondary answer to Mimikyu and Zeraora, respectively. These teammates also appreciate Sneasler's ability to remove Toxic Spikes, greatly easing the matchup against Water and Poison teams.

Choice Scarf (Poison).description: Sneasler finds a role as Poison's premier Choice Scarf user thanks to its incredible Speed allowing it to outpace opposing Choice Scarf users like Iron Treads and Tapu Lele, as well as its great Attack and movepool. Dire Claw allows Sneasler to potentially inflict status onto threats like Dragonite and Tornadus-T attempting to check it. U-turn allows Sneasler to pivot out of threats that wall it like Great Tusk and Clodsire. Switcheroo messes with opposing walls such as Corviknight and Clodsire, while Rock Slide is a strong option to check threats such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Nidoking and Sneasler pair excellently together, creating a great offensive core, as Nidoking can set Stealth Rock to provide chip damage and remove targets like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Zapdos that prove problematic to Sneasler, while Sneasler can remove faster threats and special walls such as Kyurem, Enamorus, and Blissey. Galarian Slowking can take on special threats such as Choice Specs Latios and Tornadus-T, along with using Future Sight to pair with Sneasler's Close Combat to deal immense damage to threats. Alolan Muk provides great support by dealing with and Pursuit trapping Ghost- and Psychic-type foes that Sneasler cannot handle such as Blacephalon, Hisuian Zoroark, and Deoxys-S. Crobat provides entry hazard removal and removes targets like Mega Gallade that can cause significant issues. Mega Venusaur can handle Ground- and Water-type threats such as Great Tusk, Hippowdon, Urshifu-R, and Dondozo. Toxapex can handle powerful priority attacks from the likes of Scizor, Hisuian Arcanine, and Mimikyu attempting to pick Sneasler off by punishing their users with Scald burns and removing their boosts with Haze.

Choice Scarf (Flying).description: Enamorus provides great speed control for Flying teams, outspeeding and threatening a myriad of common threats such as Mega Altaria, boosted Kommo-o, Mega Lopunny, Hisuian Lilligant, and Choice Specs Greninja. Earth Power pairs well with Moonblast, hitting Poison-, Steel-, and Fire-types that resist Moonblast like Toxapex, Heatran, and Cinderace. On the other hand, Mystical Fire targets the likes of Ferrothorn, Skarmory, and Corviknight; however, Earth Power is preferred due to the greater number of targets it hits. Superpower not only hits threats like Empoleon and Ogerpon-C, but it can also help Enamorus snowball through Normal and Rock teams thanks to Contrary boosting. Healing Wish allows Enamorus to cure status and grant longevity to a weakened teammate. Gliscor and Landorus both provide entry hazard support and Electric immunity, and Landorus also wallbreaks to enable a sweep from Enamorus. Corviknight and Mantine remove Stealth Rock for Enamorus with Defog, and they can switch into Sneasler and Mega Swampert, respectively. Mega Charizard Y and Tornadus-T both handle bulky threats like Mega Venusaur and Swampert. In return, Enamorus provides Healing Wish support. Mega Aerodactyl forms a great revenge killing core with Enamorus, handling Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Galarian Slowking for Enamorus while also appreciating Enamorus removing Choice Scarf Nihilego.

Choice Scarf (Dark).description: Thanks to its fantastic movepool and Protean, Choice Scarf Meowscarada is the best revenge killer available for Dark teams, outrunning the likes of Regieleki, Speed-boosted Kommo-o, and Mega Swampert under rain. Flower Trick is Meowscarada's most powerful move, picking off weakened foes such as Tapu Lele and Terrakion. Play Rough is essential, as it deals with many threats to Dark teams like Galarian Zapdos, Mega Gallade, and Iron Valiant. U-turn allows Meowscarada to switch out of unfavorable situations, pivoting into powerful teammates such as Galarian Moltres and Mega Tyranitar while keeping momentum for the team. Knock Off cripples defensive switch-ins—such as Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Clefable—as well as offensive Pokemon like Zeraora and Iron Treads. Toxic Spikes can be run instead to better pressure Normal, Fairy, and Fighting teams. Meowscarada's teammates appreciate its ability to check a myriad of threats as well as its revenge killing capabilities. Wallbreakers like Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon are great partners to deal with physical walls like Celesteela and Mega Venusaur. Ting-Lu and Tyranitar provide entry hazard support for Meowscarada—ensuring it is able to net more KO's—and are great defensive pivots for it to fall back upon. Similarly, Mega Sableye provides a Fighting immunity, bounces back status moves, and prevents entry hazards from going up, letting Meowscarada switch in unscathed.

Choice Scarf (Grass).description: Meowscarada is an excellent choice for Grass teams thanks to its high Speed and Protean, enabling it to be a threatening revenge killer that can outspeed common threats such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and Gholdengo. Flower Trick is Meowscarada's best STAB option and is capable of dealing with weakened Pokemon like Clodsire and Spectrier. Flower Trick's guaranteed critical hit is also very useful in the Fairy matchup and lets Meowscarada revenge kill Azumarill and a weakened Tapu Lele behind Reflect. U-turn allows Meowscarada to maintain an advantage against its defensive checks like Corviknight by being able to pivot into its teammates like Scovillain. Knock Off is a tool to cripple Meowscarada's defensive switch-ins like Toxapex and Klefki in addition to the aforementioned Corviknight. Play Rough is a strong coverage option to threaten opposing Dragon-type Pokemon like Kommo-o, Kyurem, and Latios, which Grass teams tend to struggle against. Low Kick is a less frequent option but lets Meowscarada OHKO Bisharp while threatening Heatran with a 2HKO; however, Play Rough is preferred to have an easier time against Dragon teams. Meowscarada has an easier time revenge killing foes with entry hazard support from Ferrothorn and Cradily. Ferrothorn appreciates Meowscarada's ability to check Fighting-types like Mega Gallade, Iron Valiant and Galarian Zapdos with STAB Play Rough. Hisuian Lilligant is also a fantastic offensive partner for Meowscarada. It is able to check the Flying-types that switch into Meowscarada like Celesteela and Landorus-T while also assisting in the Dragon matchup, outspeeding common Pokemon like Garchomp and Dragonite. Hisuian Lilligant also makes the Steel matchup easier for Grass; its ability to threaten Heatran is appreciated by Meowscarada, while Meowscarada can threaten Gholdengo with Knock Off, which Lilligant cannot beat. Mega Venusaur is also a mandatory defensive partner for Meowscarada; its Bug neutrality and bulk allows it to act as a consistent check to Mega Scizor, which easily switches into any move of Meowscarada, and Venusaur is able to check it with Hidden Power Fire. Mega Venusaur also checks opposing Fairy-types for Meowscarada like Tapu Koko, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant, while Meowscarada is able to threaten the Psychic-types that force out Mega Venusaur such as Latios, Mega Alakazam, and Victini. Whismicott is one of the best hazard removal options on Grass, and Meowscarada appreciates not having Stealth Rock and Spikes chip it down, because it comes in often to threaten a KO. Whimsicott's Fairy typing also allows Meowscarada and its teammates not to be overwhelmed by Dragon-types like Garchomp, and it can encore Calm Mind Mega Latias. Celebi with Nasty Plot and Groundium Z can break defensive Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra while also being able to threaten opposing Poison-types like Alolan Muk and Toxapex.

Swords Dance (Fire).description: Ceruledge is a strong late-game sweeper on Fire teams that checks Ghost- and Psychic-types thanks to its powerful STAB moves, setup in Swords Dance, and a great ability in Weak Armor, punishing physical attackers that hit it. At +2, Ceruledge 2HKOes Great Tusk and has a good chance to OHKO Gliscor after Stealth Rock damage with Poltergeist. Shadow Sneak allows Ceruledge to take out boosted albeit weakened Pokemon like Dragonite, Alolan Raichu, Iron Boulder, and opposing Ceruledge. With Focus Sash, Ceruledge ensures its Weak Armor is activated from most physical attacks, and it lets Ceruledge set up Swords Dance once. Cinderace and Torkoal are great partners for Ceruledge, as they provide entry hazard control with Court Change and Rapid Spin, respectively, so that its Focus Sash is kept intact. Additionally, Torkoal sets up sun to further boost Ceruledge's Bitter Blade and Stealth Rock to aid its sweeping, while Cinderace targets Dark-types such as Ting-Lu, Hydreigon, and Tyranitar, which can pose challenges to Ceruledge's sweeping. Wallbreakers such as Choice Band Victini and Mega Charizard X remove bulky Pokemon that Ceruledge dislikes. Victini takes on Water-types such as Tapu Fini, Urshifu-R, and Dondozo, while Mega Charizard X breaks past Heatran. In return, Victini appreciates Ceruledge handling Psychic-types like Iron Boulder and Mega Latias. Hisuian Arcanine revenge kills boosted sweepers such as Roaring Moon so that Ceruledge can sweep, and it can threaten Flying-types such as Galarian Moltres and Zapdos. Ceruledge can also enable other sweepers and cleaners such as Volcarona by removing Pokemon that threaten them such as Skeledirge so they can start their own sweep.

Swords Dance (Ghost).description: With its high Attack stat, powerful STAB combination, access to Swords Dance, and a great ability in Weak Armor, Ceruledge becomes an incredible wallbreaker for Ghost teams, hitting walls like Heatran, Hisuian Goodra, and Alolan Muk. At +2, Poltergeist outright OHKOs non-Unaware Clodsire and OHKO Mega Sableye, Swampert, and Heatran after a layer of Spikes. Bitter Blade allows Ceruledge to deal with Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Scizor while restoring its HP, letting it reactivate Focus Sash if not already consumed. Shadow Sneak allows Ceruledge to revenge kill weakened threats like Barraskewda, Iron Boulder, and opposing Ceruledge while also letting it clean opposing Ghost teams. Focus Sash guarantees that Ceruledge activates Weak Armor if it's hit with a physical attack while setting up with Swords Dance. Weak Armor's activation allows Ceruledge to outspeed faster threats like Mega Lopunny and Choice Scarf users like Meowscarada, Iron Boulder, and the Landorus formes. Mimikyu handles Dark-types like Mandibuzz, Ting-Lu, and Hydreigon, and, in return, Ceruledge can deal with Steel- and Poison-types like Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Mega Venusaur. Sinistcha boasts Water and Ground resistances, which allow it to check foes like Ogerpon-W, Urshifu-R, and Great Tusk. Mega Sableye provides entry hazard control, allowing Ceruledge to maintain its Focus Sash. Galarian Corsola and Brambleghast set entry hazards, which makes it easier for Ceruledge to break through bulky foes. Additionally, Brambleghast provides entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin while also providing the same resistances as Sinistcha. Hisuian Zoroark, Gengar, and Gholdengo are excellent partners that help Ceruledge against physical walls like Archaludon, Toxapex, and Great Tusk. In return, Ceruledge deals with special walls such as Clodsire, Blissey, Swampert, and Hisuian Goodra.

Water Absorb (Ground).description: Due to its incredible bulk and the ability to neutralize Water-type moves with Water Absorb, Clodsire is a staple for Ground teams, as it is able to stop threats such as Pelipper, Tapu Fini, and Rotom-W. Poison Jab not only spreads status but also lets it hit Grass- and Fairy-type Pokemon such as Tapu Bulu, Ogerpon-W, and Enamorus. Pairing Haze up with Icium Z allows Clodsire the ability to recover any damage from setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Ogerpon-W, and Kommo-o. The given EV spread allows Clodsire avoid a 2KHO from Choice Scarf Meowscarada with Flower Trick, unboosted Ogerpon-W with Horn Leech, and Choice Scarf Greninja with Ice Beam. Landorus provides an immunity to Ground-type moves that threaten Clodsire and offensively threatens Pokemon like Tapu Bulu, Celebi, and Archaludon. Hippowdon is a phenomenal defensive teammate, as it provides Stealth Rock support along with setting sand upon switching in. Hippowdon also defensively supports Clodsire by checking the likes of Ceruledge, Great Tusk, and Iron Hands. Excadrill, in conjunction with sand, is a powerful wallbreaker for Clodsire that can outspeed many Pokemon and deal raw damage with a Choice Band, checking threats such as Tapu Lele, Greninja, and Mega Gallade. Garchomp is an effective teammate that assists by checking Dragon-type threats such as Kommo-o and Kyurem. Mamoswine is another great teammate for Clodsire, as its Ice typing and powerful STAB moves assists in checking threats like the Landorus formes and Dragonite. Both Mamoswine and Garchomp deal offensive pressure to Steel- and Flying types such as Celesteela and Corviknight, which Clodsire cannot do on its own.

Unaware (Poison).description: Clodsire is an incredible specially defensive wall for Poison teams thanks to its solid stats and ability in Unaware, making it a solid check into special threats such as Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Gholdengo. Low Kick is used to break Hydreigon's Substitute along with popping Air Balloon from Heatran, while Poison Jab can be used to spread poison and do consistent damage to Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T. Clodsire's access to both Spikes and Stealth Rock provides it with good opportunities to set entry hazards, with Stealth Rock being preferred because it damages every Pokemon. Alternatively, Curse can patch up Clodsire's poor physical stats and make it a win condition. Mega Venusaur serves as a great defensive compliment to Clodsire with its ability to handle Water- and Ground-types like Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, Great Tusk, and Excadrill. Alolan Muk supports Clodsire by dealing with special attackers that threaten Clodsire like Latios, Tapu Lele, and Celebrate Victini. Crobat provides a solid Ground immunity, Defog to remove entry hazards while checking threats like Mega Gallade and Ogerpon-W, and Toxic to help outlast opponents. Choice Scarf Nihilego supports Clodsire by removing Ice- and Flying-types like Weavile, Mega Aerodactyl, the Landorus formes, and Mega Charizard Y. Choice Scarf Sneasler can help remove problematic faster threats like Choice Scarf Excadrill, Weavile, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele while greatly appreciating Clodsire's hazards to damage Porygon2 and Rotom-W, along with its ability to use Switcheroo to force an unwanted Choice Scarf onto targets like Corviknight.

Choiced Attacker (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Bulk Up (Ground).description: Great Tusk is a deadly wallbreaker on Ground teams, possessing excellent stats, a potent STAB combination, and access to utility moves like Knock Off and Rapid Spin. Close Combat threatens Ice- and Dark-types such as Baxcalibur, Hydreigon, and Hisuian Samurott as well as OHKOing walls like Celesteela, Corviknight, Mega Scizor, and Rotom-W with the aid of Fightinium Z after a Bulk Up boost, easing the Steel matchup for Great Tusk's team. Earthquake hits Pokemon like Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Toxapex, while Ice Spinner nails Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Zapdos, allowing Great Tusk to boast unresisted coverage in combination with Close Combat. Rapid Spin allows Great Tusk to gain a Speed boost to easily snowball against slower teams and remove entry hazards for teammates; however, Knock Off is great for Air Balloon Gholdengo and weakened Slowbro as well as generally forcing progress against teams by removing their items. Gastrodon and Clodsire are essential teammates for Great Tusk due to their immunities to Water-type attacks, letting them fend off Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, and Keldeo. Gastrodon also has an appreciated neutrality to Ice-type attacks, letting it check Choice Scarf Weavile, and Clodsire is neutral to Grass-type attacks, letting it wall Meowscarada. It can also wall Fairy-types like Tapu Koko, Tapu Fini, and Iron Valiant. Furthermore, Gastrodon and Clodsire provide chip damage via Toxic and entry hazards, wearing down walls like Slowbro, Swampert, and Mantine that give Great Tusk a hard time. Landorus forms a potent wallbreaking core with Great Tusk, breaking Slowbro, Dondozo, and Mandibuzz as well as offering Gravity, letting Great Tusk more easily spam Earthquake. In return, Landorus appreciates Great Tusk threatening Ice Shard users like Mamoswine and Baxcalibur. Mega Steelix is an excellent teammate, as it fights off Azumarill, Weavile, and Alolan Ninetales, making it a huge asset in the Fairy and Ice matchups. Ting-Lu forms an entry hazard-stacking core with Gastrodon and Clodsire, wearing down teams exponentially faster with the help of Whirlwind. Additionally, Ting-Lu switches into attacks from revenge killers like Blacephalon, Latias, and Hisuian Zoroark. Mamoswine appreciates Great Tusk breaking Celesteela and Corviknight; in return, Mamoswine utilizes Thick Fat to fight the aforementioned Ice-types and provides speed control with Choice Scarf, outpacing Mega Diancie, Enamorus, and Tapu Koko. Choice Scarf Iron Treads outpaces and OHKOes the aforementioned Fairy-types, most notably Iron Valiant, and provides pivoting support via Volt Switch.

Choice Scarf (Ground).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Steel).description: Iron Treads is a great Choice Scarf user on Steel teams due to its great Speed tier, notably allowing it to outpace Volcarona after a Quiver Dance and Mega Charizard X after a Dragon Dance. It also has a great variety of coverage moves, aiding against Landorus and the aforementioned Fire-types. Earthquake targets threats such as Heatran, Zeraora, Sneasler, and Gholdengo. Iron Head hits Fairy-types like Tapu Bulu, Iron Valiant, and Enamorus, while Volt Switch allows Iron Treads to maintain momentum and pivot out of unfavorable switch-ins like Pelipper and Slowbro. Ice Spinner hits Ground- and Dragon-types such as Landorus, Dragonite, and Garchomp while also aiding in the Flying matchup, removing Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Gliscor. Furthermore, Ice Spinner removes Psychic Terrain for Mega Scizor, which relies on Bullet Punch. Stone Edge threatens Fire- and Flying-types like Volcarona, Articuno, and Mega Charizard Y. Alternatively, Knock Off pressures defensive switch-ins such as Rotom-W, Celesteela, and Ferrothorn while also being Iron Treads's best move against Air Balloon Gholdengo and Latias. Iron Treads can provide emergency entry hazard removal via Rapid Spin for faster-paced Steel teams. Hard Press is a niche option to remove frail targets like Meowscarada; however, Iron Head allows Iron Treads to revenge kill weakened Pokemon. Gholdengo is an excellent teammate that greatly capitalizes on Z-Moves, offers a Fighting-type immunity, and acts as a situational Ground-type immunity with Air Balloon. It also removes walls like Slowbro, Corviknight, and defensive Great Tusk. In return, Iron Treads offers a valuable answer to Fire-types such as Cinderace, Volcanion, and Victini. Heatran absorbs Fire-type attacks from faster threats like Choice Scarf Blacephalon and Iron Moth, in addition to setting up Stealth Rock to wear down switch-ins for Iron Treads. Celesteela and Corviknight offer a Ground-type immunity, walling Sand Rush Excadrill and Hippowdon. Furthermore, Corviknight provides slow pivoting via U-turn, while Celesteela pressures foes with residual chip damage using Toxic and Leech Seed. In exchange, Iron Treads threatens Electric-type Pokemon like Tapu Koko, Regieleki, and Sandy Shocks, as well as Fire teams, removing Hisuian Arcanine and Ceruledge once its Focus Sash has been broken. Ferrothorn is a great buffer against Water- and Ground- types like Gastrodon, Swampert, Mamoswine, and Slowking. Additionally, Ferrothorn boasts an array of utility options such as Leech Seed, Knock Off, and Spikes, wearing down Iron Treads's switch-ins and allowing for a free Stone Edge moveslot.

Assault Vest (Electric).description:
Survives Dragonite's +2 Earthquake and is not 2HKO'ed by Mega Charizard-Y. Outspeeds Blissey and OHKO's Garchomp with Ice Punch under Electric terrain.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Fire).description: Choice Scarf Iron Moth makes for a great cleaner on Fire teams by virtue of its diverse moveset and being able to outspeed Mega Swampert and non-Choice Scarf Greninja. Energy Ball handles Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Greninja, Mega Diancie, and Great Tusk. Sludge Wave targets the Ogerpon formes as well as Fairy-types such as Enamorus and Tapu Koko. Dazzling Gleam covers threats such as Hydreigon and Kommo-o. Torkoal sets up sun to boost Iron Moth's Fiery Dance to make it a more terrifying snowballing option and Stealth Rock to aid Iron Moth's cleaning, notably breaking Focus Sash and Sturdy from their users. Both Torkoal and Cinderace also serve as entry hazard control with Rapid Spin and Court Change, respectively, and the latter can bring Iron Moth in with U-turn to keep momentum. Mega Charizard X and Hisuian Arcanine pair well with Iron Moth, as they take on Heatran and Blissey, which otherwise wall Iron Moth. Heatran itself serves as a great partner, as due to its access to Magma Storm and Taunt, it can shut down and eliminate walls such as Toxapex. In return, Heatran appreciates Iron Moth taking on Ground-types such as Great Tusk, Mega Swampert, and Gastrodon. Thanks to Iron Moth's ability to take on bulky foes such as Mega Sableye and Tapu Fini as well as speedy Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Choice Scarf Enamorus, it can enable late-game sweepers such as Ceruledge and Volcarona to begin their own sweep.

Z-Move (Ghost).description: Having a typing with a lot of relevant resistances, an immunity to status moves thanks to Good as Gold, and great longevity by virtue of having Recover, Gholdengo is a potent stallbreaker for Ghost teams. Shadow Ball hits most foes for neutral damage, with Never-Ending Nightmare at +2 OHKOing foes such as Mega Sableye, Galarian Slowking, and Corviknight. Make It Rain lets Gholdengo hit foes such as Alolan Muk, Mandibuzz, and Kommo-o, as well as OHKO Ice- and Fairy-type foes such as Mamoswine, Alolan Ninetales, and Iron Valiant, and at +2, this move OHKOes Gliscor, Hippowdon, and Ursaluna. The given EV spread allows Gholdengo to outspeed Adamant Mamoswine and avoid a 2HKO from Mega Scizor's Knock Off, Ogerpon-C's Knock Off after Stealth Rock, and Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Thunderbolt. Mega Sableye forms a good defensive core with Gholdengo, as Mega Sableye mitigates its vulnerability to Dark- and Ghost-type foes such as Meowscarada, Greninja, and Hisuian Zoroark, while Gholdengo handles Fairy-types including Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Sinistcha can switch into Ground-types such as Garchomp, Mega Swampert, and Great Tusk that Gholdengo is vulnerable to. Fire-types such as Ceruledge and Skeledirge are solid partners that can check other Fire-types that force out Gholdengo such as Cinderace, Victini, and Volcarona.
